Posts.Content: Hey...I would never crack wise on you, Prato. Deja Vu...these two fine forums need to be combined I've already given you two good links. So for the benefit of those who don't go 'over there', I'll say again: Basically any machine that delivers IMRT/IGRT or SBRT are going to be equally safe. The Varian class machines use a method where they continuously deliver the radiation while the gantry is moving around the body. Other machines do a start and stop method. The Varian is not safer, per se, it is just faster. The actual zapping/IMRT from a Varian machine takes about six minutes. The only real advantage seems to be time, and the much reduced chance of you, and your organs moving around while being zapped. The advantage to the radiation center is that they can treat more people in the same amount of time and thus make more money. Technology development isn't just oriented for client effectiveness, it also generate additional revenue. As to choosing the center, they will all have to follow the same accepted protocols for safety. MSK is very well regarded and does a lot of PCa work. The convenience to you will be valuable. As already said, it's is the people, not the brand of machine that's the most important factor. Near the end of the treatment, they sometimes narrow the beam and zero in on likely troublesome areas. In my case, they referred to this as a 3.6 Gy "boost".. Picture this...The older LINACS, the x-ray machines that deliver the radiation, usually moved into position and stopped, became stationary, while the dose was administered. It would then move on to a new position and fire again..Typically, it would repeat this 7 times during a treatment session. This reduced the exposure to healthy tissue to one seventh of what the target received..With the newer LINACS, the gantry is in motion (Rapid-Arc/Edge) when the beam is activated so healthy tissue receives much less exposure..The RO, with help, writes a treatment plan, a dose volume histogram, so these moving arcs seldom if ever overlap as the gantry can accommodate a wide range of motion, but the target, the focal point, receives the full intended dose..Also, the new machines have a built-in CAT scanner that checks organ position just before the beam is activated...If anything has moved out of position for any reason the beam is aborted until the situation is corrected, and the control room that the techs are in while you're being zapped is most impressive, with an array of PC's and displays. The company that developed this new technology is Varian and the first generation of these LINACS were called Rapid-Arcs. They were introduced about ten years ago. It's the minimum you should be looking for. Today, the newest models are even more advanced....Most up to date treatment centers, especially ones like MSK, even satellites being phased out, use this new equipment. Just as important is the skill of the techs and RO's that operate it. Since you worry about everything....have you checked out the bathrooms yet, Prato? They come in very handy when relieving yourself of the preparation water. Just do it, already!

Posts.Title: Dr Surprised but 'not alarmed' at PSA after surgery.

Posts.Content: Dr. Tewari does a frozen section during surgery for a quick pathology check. A worthwhile procedure IMHO, not often done. Takes more time and drives up the cost. You can thank Allen Edel for this list of questions: Questions to ask (and not ask) on a first urologist visit after a biopsy Am I a good candidate for surgery? What about anatomic abnormalities, previous hernia, effects of anesthesia, cardiovascular disease, diabetes or other comorbidities? I would like to get a second opinion on my biopsy slides from Epstein's lab at Johns Hopkins. What is my highest Gleason score? How many cores were positive? What was the highest percent of cancer in any core? What is my stage, and risk level? (You should know your PSA – if you don’t, ask). How big is my prostate, and what is my prostate density? If stage is T3 or T4: How can surgery be a good option if only the prostate capsule is taken out, leaving the rest behind? Aren’t the side effects of adjuvant radiation worse than if I had radiation at the start? (he may not know this.) Am I a candidate for active surveillance (why, why not), and if so, what are your Active Surveillance criteria and protocol? Why those and not something more or less stringent? Should I get a genetic test before deciding? Will that be covered by insurance? How many of the surgery technique you practice (whether robotic, laparoscopic or open) have you performed? (1000+ would be a good answer) Are you going to be doing all of the really important parts of my procedure yourself? (You need to be particularly careful about this at major training institutions where residents may be doing some parts of the surgery, or even the whole operation, while “your” surgeon is overseeing it.) In the last year, what was your positive surgical margin rate? (Should be less than 10% among men with stage pT2) What is your "trifecta" rate? (tricky because you don't want cherry-picked patients) What is your estimate of my risk for lasting incontinence; i.e., a pad or more after a year? What about lasting stress incontinence? climacturia? penile shrinkage? inguinal hernia? Peyronie’s? orgasmic pain or dysfunction? What kind of anastomosis technique do you use? (total - not just anterior) Will the bladder neck be spared? How will you maximize the urethral sparing? If you have positive biopsy cores near the apex: How will you ensure that all cancerous tissue is removed there? Will you take frozen sections and have a pathologist standing by to determine margins and how much of neurovascular bundles can be spared? What measures will you take to assure the integrity of the neurovascular bundles? What kind of penile rehab do you suggest? What kind of imaging (Bone scan, CT or MRI) is necessary for men at my risk level? Will you sample lymph nodes (PLND) or take extended lymph nodes (ePLND), or does it seem unnecessary for my risk level? If so, how will you find them (fluorescent dye)? How will you minimize risk of lymphocele and lymphedema? What kind of aftercare (including sexual rehab) will you provide, and how will we monitor side effects, and for how long? Will you regularly monitor my urinary and erectile recovery progress with validated questionnaires like EPIC and IPSS? How will I be monitored for recurrence? Will I get an ultrasensitive PSA test? How will you decide the point at which you would recommend I see a radiation oncologist? Do you use the Decipher test? Questions not to ask: Is my age a factor in whether active surveillance is right for me? (only you can decide whether you are willing to live more years with the side effects of treatment, or whether you prefer to be treated while younger when side effects are apt to be less - see this link) What treatments should I consider and which is the best for me? (this would be asking your doctor to be an expert in treatments outside of his specialty, and also to know which benefits and risks are most important to you – he doesn’t have time or inclination to be expert in all therapies, and he’s not a mind reader.) If I were your father, what would you recommend? (You don’t know how he feels about his father (lol), and more importantly, what he would feel most comfortable with is not necessarily what you would feel most comfortable with. This is your decision to make and live with – don’t give up your power!)

In the last year, what was your positive surgical margin rate? (Should be less than 10% among men with stage pT2) What is your "trifecta" rate? (tricky because you don't want cherry-picked patients) What is your estimate of my risk for lasting incontinence; i.e., a pad or more after a year? What about lasting stress incontinence? climacturia? penile shrinkage? inguinal hernia? Peyronie’s? orgasmic pain or dysfunction? What kind of anastomosis technique do you use? (total - not just anterior) Will the bladder neck be spared? How will you maximize the urethral sparing? If you have positive biopsy cores near the apex: How will you ensure that all cancerous tissue is removed there? Will you take frozen sections and have a pathologist standing by to determine margins and how much of neurovascular bundles can be spared? What measures will you take to assure the integrity of the neurovascular bundles? What kind of penile rehab do you suggest? What kind of imaging (Bone scan, CT or MRI) is necessary for men at my risk level? Will you sample lymph nodes (PLND) or take extended lymph nodes (ePLND), or does it seem unnecessary for my risk level? If so, how will you find them (fluorescent dye)? How will you minimize risk of lymphocele and lymphedema? What kind of aftercare (including sexual rehab) will you provide, and how will we monitor side effects, and for how long? Will you regularly monitor my urinary and erectile recovery progress with validated questionnaires like EPIC and IPSS? How will I be monitored for recurrence? Will I get an ultrasensitive PSA test? How will you decide the point at which you would recommend I see a radiation oncologist? Do you use the Decipher test? Questions not to ask: Is my age a factor in whether active surveillance is right for me? (only you can decide whether you are willing to live more years with the side effects of treatment, or whether you prefer to be treated while younger when side effects are apt to be less - see this link) What treatments should I consider and which is the best for me? (this would be asking your doctor to be an expert in treatments outside of his specialty, and also to know which benefits and risks are most important to you – he doesn’t have time or inclination to be expert in all therapies, and he’s not a mind reader.) If I were your father, what would you recommend? (You don’t know how he feels about his father (lol), and more importantly, what he would feel most comfortable with is not necessarily what you would feel most comfortable with. This is your decision to make and live with – don’t give up your power!)

Posts.Content: Hey...I would never crack wise on you, Prato. Deja Vu...these two fine forums need to be combined I've already given you two good links. So for the benefit of those who don't go 'over there', I'll say again: Basically any machine that delivers IMRT/IGRT or SBRT are going to be equally safe. The Varian class machines use a method where they continuously deliver the radiation while the gantry is moving around the body. Other machines do a start and stop method. The Varian is not safer, per se, it is just faster. The actual zapping/IMRT from a Varian machine takes about six minutes. The only real advantage seems to be time, and the much reduced chance of you, and your organs moving around while being zapped. The advantage to the radiation center is that they can treat more people in the same amount of time and thus make more money. Technology development isn't just oriented for client effectiveness, it also generate additional revenue. As to choosing the center, they will all have to follow the same accepted protocols for safety. MSK is very well regarded and does a lot of PCa work. The convenience to you will be valuable. As already said, it's is the people, not the brand of machine that's the most important factor. Near the end of the treatment, they sometimes narrow the beam and zero in on likely troublesome areas. In my case, they referred to this as a 3.6 Gy "boost".. Picture this...The older LINACS, the x-ray machines that deliver the radiation, usually moved into position and stopped, became stationary, while the dose was administered. It would then move on to a new position and fire again..Typically, it would repeat this 7 times during a treatment session. This reduced the exposure to healthy tissue to one seventh of what the target received..With the newer LINACS, the gantry is in motion (Rapid-Arc/Edge) when the beam is activated so healthy tissue receives much less exposure..The RO, with help, writes a treatment plan, a dose volume histogram, so these moving arcs seldom if ever overlap as the gantry can accommodate a wide range of motion, but the target, the focal point, receives the full intended dose..Also, the new machines have a built-in CAT scanner that checks organ position just before the beam is activated...If anything has moved out of position for any reason the beam is aborted until the situation is corrected, and the control room that the techs are in while you're being zapped is most impressive, with an array of PC's and displays. The company that developed this new technology is Varian and the first generation of these LINACS were called Rapid-Arcs. They were introduced about ten years ago. It's the minimum you should be looking for. Today, the newest models are even more advanced....Most up to date treatment centers, especially ones like MSK, even satellites being phased out, use this new equipment. Just as important is the skill of the techs and RO's that operate it. Since you worry about everything....have you checked out the bathrooms yet, Prato? They come in very handy when relieving yourself of the preparation water. Just do it, already!

Posts.Title: Radiation Equipment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joseywales Hello, Last night I got a call from local survivor. He recommended I make the drive to MD Anderson and ask for a second opinion on treatment and inquire about Proton Therapy. I made a call today and they said that based on my stats I am a potential candidate for proton treatment, but the earliest appointment that have is April 1. I'm torn between my urologist's opinion that I need surgery soon and my desire to get another opinion at MDA and review all options??? Almost all of us have been where you find yourself today, Josey. Good advise both from your friend, and from brothers here. Keep bugging MDA, and you'll get a much quicker appointment. Calling a specific doctor there will help. Check out their website. https://www.mdanderson.org/research/...lty-staff.html You do not have garden variety PCa, and the true experts at MDA are as good as it gets. Get your butt there ASAP. Don't concern yourself with any particular therapy yet, you need to better understand your diagnosis. Your urologist and surgeon are throwing around numbers they know can't be very accurate. I'd be uncomfortable with that. Do get your biopsy sides sent to Epstein at JH for a second opinion, ASAP. Where are you located, and who is your urologist and surgeon??? Don't worry...you'll get through this, and we're here to help.

Posts.Content: Surgery does seem your best option, and you’ve already spoken to two of the best. I suggest meeting with both and ask a series of direct and tough questions, some of which you already know the answers to. Then go with your gut. Remember, it isn’t necessary to like them, and a surgeon’s communication skill isn’t at the top of the list. You want someone forthright, experienced and talented. Good luck!

Should I request a second opinion from Dr. Epstein???

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate I have read that the sections on radiation in the forthcoming edition have been written by someone else. That fact may blunt some of the criticisms from radiation advocates that the previous editions were biased in favor of surgery and outdated on other treatments. Sounds like a good reason for everyone to buy this next edition. The existing book is not to be dismissed. Those with a bias toward radiation are hard pressed to offer up any even handed, scholarly, well research text. The 'book' as as good as it gets, and many of us without axes to grind don't find it in anyway biased toward any treatment. That Dr. Walsh covers surgery more extensively is quite understandable....he is a surgeon after all. IMHO he has given radiation it's just due. Read it yourselves, my brothers, and make up your own minds.

Posts.Title: Steady as she goes: PSA holding

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F .....You previously mentioned a possible personality conflict with Dr S. If surgery is your choice, toss the personality conflict out the window!!! You will be asleep during surgery and not arguing with the surgeon!!! Your objective is 100% Cure! Very true...He has the rep of being an excellent surgeon. Most of them, even the average ones, have strong egos, but aren't know to have good bedside manners. Emory is as good as you'll find in the southeast. Stay calm, positive, research and take notes. Finally pick the procedure YOU are most comfortable with. Remembering there are no silver bullets, you'll do well.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F ...... Dr Partin is at one of the world's TOP PCa Centers (JH) and has performed over 5,500 RPs so I sense that he has seen every possible outcome. He turned down your follow up appointment request based on his sound judgement. Stay strong and optimistic. We are all in this war together! MF That may be the most important point of all. I visited JHMI three times and can attest to the quality of their physicians. Dr. Partain is one of the best, and as such, his time is limited, so I'm guessing he invests it where it can do the most good. He probably turned down your request because in his considered opinion, no action is needed. A very good sign! In any event, you have a most rational plan. Fingers crossed.

Posts.Title: Dr Surprised but 'not alarmed' at PSA after surgery.

Posts.Content: Dr. Tewari does a frozen section during surgery for a quick pathology check. A worthwhile procedure IMHO, not often done. Takes more time and drives up the cost. You can thank Allen Edel for this list of questions: Questions to ask (and not ask) on a first urologist visit after a biopsy Am I a good candidate for surgery? What about anatomic abnormalities, previous hernia, effects of anesthesia, cardiovascular disease, diabetes or other comorbidities? I would like to get a second opinion on my biopsy slides from Epstein's lab at Johns Hopkins. What is my highest Gleason score? How many cores were positive? What was the highest percent of cancer in any core? What is my stage, and risk level? (You should know your PSA – if you don’t, ask). How big is my prostate, and what is my prostate density? If stage is T3 or T4: How can surgery be a good option if only the prostate capsule is taken out, leaving the rest behind? Aren’t the side effects of adjuvant radiation worse than if I had radiation at the start? (he may not know this.) Am I a candidate for active surveillance (why, why not), and if so, what are your Active Surveillance criteria and protocol? Why those and not something more or less stringent? Should I get a genetic test before deciding? Will that be covered by insurance? How many of the surgery technique you practice (whether robotic, laparoscopic or open) have you performed? (1000+ would be a good answer) Are you going to be doing all of the really important parts of my procedure yourself? (You need to be particularly careful about this at major training institutions where residents may be doing some parts of the surgery, or even the whole operation, while “your” surgeon is overseeing it.) In the last year, what was your positive surgical margin rate? (Should be less than 10% among men with stage pT2) What is your "trifecta" rate? (tricky because you don't want cherry-picked patients) What is your estimate of my risk for lasting incontinence; i.e., a pad or more after a year? What about lasting stress incontinence? climacturia? penile shrinkage? inguinal hernia? Peyronie’s? orgasmic pain or dysfunction? What kind of anastomosis technique do you use? (total - not just anterior) Will the bladder neck be spared? How will you maximize the urethral sparing? If you have positive biopsy cores near the apex: How will you ensure that all cancerous tissue is removed there? Will you take frozen sections and have a pathologist standing by to determine margins and how much of neurovascular bundles can be spared? What measures will you take to assure the integrity of the neurovascular bundles? What kind of penile rehab do you suggest? What kind of imaging (Bone scan, CT or MRI) is necessary for men at my risk level? Will you sample lymph nodes (PLND) or take extended lymph nodes (ePLND), or does it seem unnecessary for my risk level? If so, how will you find them (fluorescent dye)? How will you minimize risk of lymphocele and lymphedema? What kind of aftercare (including sexual rehab) will you provide, and how will we monitor side effects, and for how long? Will you regularly monitor my urinary and erectile recovery progress with validated questionnaires like EPIC and IPSS? How will I be monitored for recurrence? Will I get an ultrasensitive PSA test? How will you decide the point at which you would recommend I see a radiation oncologist? Do you use the Decipher test? Questions not to ask: Is my age a factor in whether active surveillance is right for me? (only you can decide whether you are willing to live more years with the side effects of treatment, or whether you prefer to be treated while younger when side effects are apt to be less - see this link) What treatments should I consider and which is the best for me? (this would be asking your doctor to be an expert in treatments outside of his specialty, and also to know which benefits and risks are most important to you – he doesn’t have time or inclination to be expert in all therapies, and he’s not a mind reader.) If I were your father, what would you recommend? (You don’t know how he feels about his father (lol), and more importantly, what he would feel most comfortable with is not necessarily what you would feel most comfortable with. This is your decision to make and live with – don’t give up your power!)

Posts.Title: Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer - choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Dr. Tewari does a frozen section during surgery for a quick pathology check. A worthwhile procedure IMHO, not often done. Takes more time and drives up the cost. You can thank Allen Edel for this list of questions: Questions to ask (and not ask) on a first urologist visit after a biopsy Am I a good candidate for surgery? What about anatomic abnormalities, previous hernia, effects of anesthesia, cardiovascular disease, diabetes or other comorbidities? I would like to get a second opinion on my biopsy slides from Epstein's lab at Johns Hopkins. What is my highest Gleason score? How many cores were positive? What was the highest percent of cancer in any core? What is my stage, and risk level? (You should know your PSA – if you don’t, ask). How big is my prostate, and what is my prostate density? If stage is T3 or T4: How can surgery be a good option if only the prostate capsule is taken out, leaving the rest behind? Aren’t the side effects of adjuvant radiation worse than if I had radiation at the start? (he may not know this.) Am I a candidate for active surveillance (why, why not), and if so, what are your Active Surveillance criteria and protocol? Why those and not something more or less stringent? Should I get a genetic test before deciding? Will that be covered by insurance? How many of the surgery technique you practice (whether robotic, laparoscopic or open) have you performed? (1000+ would be a good answer) Are you going to be doing all of the really important parts of my procedure yourself? (You need to be particularly careful about this at major training institutions where residents may be doing some parts of the surgery, or even the whole operation, while “your” surgeon is overseeing it.) In the last year, what was your positive surgical margin rate? (Should be less than 10% among men with stage pT2) What is your "trifecta" rate? (tricky because you don't want cherry-picked patients) What is your estimate of my risk for lasting incontinence; i.e., a pad or more after a year? What about lasting stress incontinence? climacturia? penile shrinkage? inguinal hernia? Peyronie’s? orgasmic pain or dysfunction? What kind of anastomosis technique do you use? (total - not just anterior) Will the bladder neck be spared? How will you maximize the urethral sparing? If you have positive biopsy cores near the apex: How will you ensure that all cancerous tissue is removed there? Will you take frozen sections and have a pathologist standing by to determine margins and how much of neurovascular bundles can be spared? What measures will you take to assure the integrity of the neurovascular bundles? What kind of penile rehab do you suggest? What kind of imaging (Bone scan, CT or MRI) is necessary for men at my risk level? Will you sample lymph nodes (PLND) or take extended lymph nodes (ePLND), or does it seem unnecessary for my risk level? If so, how will you find them (fluorescent dye)? How will you minimize risk of lymphocele and lymphedema? What kind of aftercare (including sexual rehab) will you provide, and how will we monitor side effects, and for how long? Will you regularly monitor my urinary and erectile recovery progress with validated questionnaires like EPIC and IPSS? How will I be monitored for recurrence? Will I get an ultrasensitive PSA test? How will you decide the point at which you would recommend I see a radiation oncologist? Do you use the Decipher test? Questions not to ask: Is my age a factor in whether active surveillance is right for me? (only you can decide whether you are willing to live more years with the side effects of treatment, or whether you prefer to be treated while younger when side effects are apt to be less - see this link) What treatments should I consider and which is the best for me? (this would be asking your doctor to be an expert in treatments outside of his specialty, and also to know which benefits and risks are most important to you – he doesn’t have time or inclination to be expert in all therapies, and he’s not a mind reader.) If I were your father, what would you recommend? (You don’t know how he feels about his father (lol), and more importantly, what he would feel most comfortable with is not necessarily what you would feel most comfortable with. This is your decision to make and live with – don’t give up your power!)

To wit: G3+4 confirmed; G4 = 10% Carcinoma in 15% of gland which was 16 gm (previous TURP) Organ confined Negative for EPE; Negative SV pT2c pNO pMn/a Grade: Group 2 Anterior Margins Involved by invasive carcinoma: Limited (<3mm) Length of positive margin: 0.1mm Additional margins negative for carcinoma No LN involvement of the 4 examined The pathology report was signed by a U of Miami resident. Should I request a second opinion from Dr. Epstein???

He recommended I make the drive to MD Anderson and ask for a second opinion on treatment and inquire about Proton Therapy. I made a call today and they said that based on my stats I am a potential candidate for proton treatment, but the earliest appointment that have is April 1. I'm torn between my urologist's opinion that I need surgery soon and my desire to get another opinion at MDA and review all options??? Almost all of us have been where you find yourself today, Josey. Good advise both from your friend, and from brothers here. Keep bugging MDA, and you'll get a much quicker appointment. Calling a specific doctor there will help. Check out their website. https://www.mdanderson.org/research/...lty-staff.html You do not have garden variety PCa, and the true experts at MDA are as good as it gets. Get your butt there ASAP. Don't concern yourself with any particular therapy yet, you need to better understand your diagnosis. Your urologist and surgeon are throwing around numbers they know can't be very accurate. I'd be uncomfortable with that. Do get your biopsy sides sent to Epstein at JH for a second opinion, ASAP. Where are you located, and who is your urologist and surgeon??? Don't worry...you'll get through this, and we're here to help.

Posts.Title: Zero Club Renewal at 6-months post-op

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joseywales Hello, Last night I got a call from local survivor. He recommended I make the drive to MD Anderson and ask for a second opinion on treatment and inquire about Proton Therapy. I made a call today and they said that based on my stats I am a potential candidate for proton treatment, but the earliest appointment that have is April 1. I'm torn between my urologist's opinion that I need surgery soon and my desire to get another opinion at MDA and review all options??? Almost all of us have been where you find yourself today, Josey. Good advise both from your friend, and from brothers here. Keep bugging MDA, and you'll get a much quicker appointment. Calling a specific doctor there will help. Check out their website. https://www.mdanderson.org/research/...lty-staff.html You do not have garden variety PCa, and the true experts at MDA are as good as it gets. Get your butt there ASAP. Don't concern yourself with any particular therapy yet, you need to better understand your diagnosis. Your urologist and surgeon are throwing around numbers they know can't be very accurate. I'd be uncomfortable with that. Do get your biopsy sides sent to Epstein at JH for a second opinion, ASAP. Where are you located, and who is your urologist and surgeon??? Don't worry...you'll get through this, and we're here to help.

Posts.Title: 24 down, 15 to go

Posts.Content: Basically, it is totally never over with prostate cancer. Those pesky cells can be lying in wait, no matter the type of treatment. You can defeat the active cells, but the potential for a recurrence is something we all live with for the rest of our lives. How you come to grips with this fact has a lot to do with how much you enjoy your remaining years. IMHO, stay vigilant, be informed, up to date, and RELAX.

Posts.Title: I found this article disturbing.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic .... When I asked when we could stop testing, he said Never, there are recurrences after 20 and 25 years. The only relief I might get is spacing the PSA testing out a bit more; in my case perhaps from 3 to 6 months ("We'll see," was the best carrot my doc could dangle.) I would file this under Fridge Lightbulb Questions. In any case worrying is useless: you're fine (until you're not)! Or, as A.E. Newman said "What, me worry?" At a certain point, or age, or level of health, might not many say, "screw it, I ain't worrying about it anymore."? That's my plan. Move over, Mr. Newman.

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: Hi Kyle and welcome to the club none of us wanted to join. Given the numbers youve posted, and hoping your husband is in otherwise good physical condition, his prognosis is excellent. That youre taking quick and decisive action is IMHO a big advantage. Some spend too much time becoming Google MDs. Researching PCa is important, but is can be overdone and result in indecisiveness. My cardiologist, at a renowned teaching hospital, told me that almost all physicians he knows, upon PCa diagnosis, immediately go for surgery. Some points in my surgery: 1. A recliner wasnt mandatory, just lots of pillows and roll out of bed carefully. 2. The medical team told me specifically NOT to use KY jelly on the catheter...youll get some better stuff at the hospital. 3. A good stool softener is mandatory; that first bowel movement can take several days. 4. I found an Amazon $15 abdominal binder most helpful the first several weeks. 5. Lots of Kegals, but not when the catheter is in. 6. Walk, walk, walk, then walk some more. 7. Sorry, but no sex for at least a month Best of luck! Trust your surgeon has lots of experience.

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: No Neosporin or KJ...Bacitracin is the ointment of choice. The hospital will probably give you some in a 'goody bag' when you check out. Also the hospital will most likely fasten your catheter with a StatLock. Don't be concerned about it....they have their SOP and SOC. I carried my Foley Bag around in a dollar store plastic bucket with a rope handle. Worked fine and folks didn't notice, inside, outside, and when I went back for the catheter removal. Trim that hair, keep walking, lots of kegals, and relax. Tell your surgeon he better get it all!!! You'll do fine.

Posts.Content: The odds are very high that you'll either need, or at a minimum, will do much better with someone staying with you for at least a week. If you don't have a friend or relative, the hospital should be able to get you assistance, and insurance may pay for it. Food, cleaning, a helping hand, someone to talk to, and a set of eyes to watch you will be most valuable. I suggest you arrange for it now. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic .... When I asked when we could stop testing, he said Never, there are recurrences after 20 and 25 years. The only relief I might get is spacing the PSA testing out a bit more; in my case perhaps from 3 to 6 months ("We'll see," was the best carrot my doc could dangle.) I would file this under Fridge Lightbulb Questions. In any case worrying is useless: you're fine (until you're not)! Or, as A.E. Newman said "What, me worry?" At a certain point, or age, or level of health, might not many say, "screw it, I ain't worrying about it anymore."? That's my plan. Move over, Mr. Newman.

Posts.Signature: 72...LUTS for the past 7 years TURP 2/16, G3+4 discovered 3T MRI 5/16 MRI fusion guided biopsy 6/16 14 cores; four G 3+3, one G3+4, CIPRO antibiotic = C. Diff infection 7/16 Cured with Vanco for 14 days Second 3T MRI 1/17 Worsened bulging of posterior capsule Oncotype DX GPS 3/17, LFP risk 63%, Likelihood of Low Grade Disease 81%, Likelihood of Organ Confined 80% RALP 7/13/17 Dr. Gonzaglo @ Univ of Miami G3+4 Confirmed, Organ confined pT2c pNO pMn/a Grade 2 PSA 0.32 to .54 over 3 months DCFPyl PET & ercMRI Scans - 11/17 A one inch tumor remains in prostate bed = failed surgery All met scans clear SRT, 2ADT, IMGT 70.2 Gys @1.8 per, completed 5/18 PSA <.006 9/18, .054 11/18, .070 12/18, .067 2/19 We'll see....what is not known dwarfs what is thought to be fact

Posts.Title: Interesting Case Study: 80-yr old with G 4+4 and LUTS treated with RP

Posts.Content: The odds are very high that you'll either need, or at a minimum, will do much better with someone staying with you for at least a week. If you don't have a friend or relative, the hospital should be able to get you assistance, and insurance may pay for it. Food, cleaning, a helping hand, someone to talk to, and a set of eyes to watch you will be most valuable. I suggest you arrange for it now. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Colonoscopy and RT

Posts.Content: When I thought my symptoms were 'just' BPH, I investigated the clinical trial for Prostate Artery Embolization (PAE) being conducted at the University of Miami. It's an interesting procedure, and certainly an option, BUT if one really has prostate cancer, as I did, a PAE will not indicate it. Several urologists wasted years of treatment or AS for me, by never mentioning cancer....just pushing for a TURP, or other BPH procedure.

Posts.Title: Encouraging Radiation Study

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F A neighbor/friend who is > 70 yo and a retired former high level hospital administrator at several top institutions across the U.S. did his research and opted for HDR. He went to a local top level academic teaching center and had 2 Treatments exactly 1 week apart. The "tubes" were inserted by a URO MD in a procedure suite in one building. Once in place, he was wheeled on the procedure platform to a completely different building for the radiation exposure. This was performed by a Nuclear Medicine MD in a special lead-lined suite. He is covered by Medicare. I'll ask him for an approximate breakdown of charges and distributions between URO and NM Depts. MF That is the exact procedure the HDR experts, like Dr. Demanes in CA explained to me. Medicine, being a business first, dosen’t usually follow such a protocol. The Dr. Denis used does NOT partner with a URO surgeon. One of the reasons I didn’t go that route. BTW, excellent evaluation Michael

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis I choose HBR BT due to two treatments versus more as a primary decision maker. From a Layman's perspective, it seems the fewer treatments the lower the risk for complications. Just my opinion. Keep studying the options. Denis That ignores the potential problems of having multiple catheters inserted into your perineum, especially if only an RO is doing it. An experienced urologist-surgeon should be present. While an interesting procedure, there are only a handful of experienced physicians, nationwide. There are NO silver bullets.

Posts.Title: First post-RP checkup/PSA monitoring

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club we'd all rather not be in, BOB. As usual you've gotten fine advise above. Several observations: I did the trek up to Johns Hopkins three times from south FL, and finally decided not to have surgery there, so I understand your reluctance for travel and desire for convenience. However, you can/should avail yourself of the excellent phone & e-mail advice you can get from JH, as a prior patient. You do have time. Those 0.03 and the 0.08 readings are still very low. Several more PSA's will give you a better picture, and while SRT + ADT may very well be in your future, the more research you do, the better final choices you can make. Remember surgeons get payed to cut, and radiologists get payed to zap, so advice from both JH and WVa are in your favor and an important part of your discovery process. The GA-68 PSMA PET Scan has the highest probability of picking something up, IF it exists, but even that is at much higher readings than you have right now. Keep collecting facts, and best of luck. You have a very good chance of beating this devil.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 ....Any insights that might help would be appreciated. Also, how much of continence improvement is due to passage of time post surgery as opposed to learning how/when to kegle? The passage of time is key, and Kegals, if you don't overdo them, are a real help. A week post catheter removal...be thankful you're not leaking like a sieve. It takes time, patience, and some work. You may want to consider PT in a month, if your incontinence is still intolerable for you. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis Thanks, guys. I am clear this is the right treatment for me. And I will continue to inquire and share what I find and I really appreciate all you do for these forums. Denis That's good, as long as it's not through rose colored glasses, Denis, as your title for this thread suggests. There are some reports that are not so glowing, that you may or may not have run across. I'm certain, that at this point, you HOPE HDR mono brachy is 'the right treatment' for you. I hope so, too. But just like RT, AS, or surgery, no intervention is perfect for ALL, and no intervention is without it's own challenges. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy AND Cystoscopy

Posts.Content: Worrying, especially at those low readings, is wasted energy. Heck, the worry itself can cause inflammation which tends to raise PSA readings. So please try to RELAX, your efforts and surgery were certainly "worth it". You ARE undetectable! Suggest you read my Self-Pity 101 thread Do get those stats and signature to us.

Posts.Title: Latest PSA = 4.29. Follow up biopsy in 2 weeks

Posts.Content: The full paper is a most interesting read. Good find, Djin! A clip from it that many should take note of is: <<<Oncotype Dx Prostate, Promark, and Decipher are multimarker tests that, similar to PTEN, are more specific to prostate cancer. Oncotype Dx Prostate and Promark are developed for the prediction of the presence of adverse pathology. Decipher appears to have utility in predicting metastasis and death following prostatectomy.>>> Basically Decipher should be used after surgery, and the other genome tests utilized before treatment, to help predict the possibility of poor pathology. It's amazing how few urologists know this. Mine didn't, until I pointed it out, as my signature below will attest to. I discovered this reading the 2015 Harvard Annual Report on Prostate Diseases. It is an excellent source of prostate science. As definitive and objective read as I have found: "2017 Annual Report on Prostate Diseases", 118 pages, Harvard Health Publications. Updated yearly. https://www.health.harvard.edu/

Posts.Content: Best wishes for an undetectable...Jared. So what did your Uro have to say? From what I read, a PSMA DCFPyL PET Scan, coupled with an erc3TMRI is about as good as can be done in the USA. There is a free clinical trial for the PET Scan at the NCI in Bethesda. I had it and they found a one inch tumor in my otherwise empty prostate cavity. Try as they could, no tiny mets were seen. Two months of 2ADT down, and SRT starts next week.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Actually, LDR BT has a very good record of outcomes compared to most other PCa treatments. Its biggest drawback is a shortage of practitioners, which I have heard is attributed to lower payments from insurance providers. Limited long term results is a concern, skilled and experienced physicians are tough to find, and as cynical as I’ve become about some medical ‘professionals’ I still find it hard to accept that insurance remuneration is a major cause. There must be more serious reservations.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by john4803 Have you read anything challenging the duo, because I am definitely interested? So, otherwise, I will report back, next week. No, I haven’t and it isn’t for lack of trying. Can’t find any specific studies and I get blank stares when asking doctors. I’m on the 2ADT at the recommendation of Dr. Anthony D’Amico, the head of RO at Daner Farmer, a Harvard Professor, with a PhD in radiation oncology from MIT....and the ‘godfather of RO.’ I visited him about five months ago for a second+++ opinion. Like most old school superstars, he is very aggressive with treatment, and offered only his own experience as justification. I ran with it, but am still dubious about the measured risk/reward benefits of ADT for many of us. Double ADT just compounds my doubts, but I let them “throw the kitchen sink at” ME. What you learn next week should be interesting. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Prediction Medicine: Biomarkers, Risk Calculators & MRI as Risk Stratification Tools

Posts.Content: Crohn's, Ulcerative Colitis May Be Tied to Prostate Cancer FRIDAY, Dec. 14, 2018 (HealthDay News) -- Men with inflammatory bowel disease have a significantly greater risk of prostate cancer, a new study finds. about 1 million men in the United States have inflammatory bowel disease, which includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. "These patients may need to be screened more carefully than a man without inflammatory bowel disease," said study lead author Dr. Shilajit Kundu. Screening for prostate cancer begins with a blood test called a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test. PSA is a substance made by the prostate gland. "If a man with inflammatory bowel disease has an elevated PSA, it may be an indicator of prostate cancer," said Kundu, an associate professor of urology at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine in Chicago. For the study, researchers looked at more than 1,000 men with inflammatory bowel disease and a "control group" of more than 9,300 men without the disease. The men were followed for 18 years. Men with inflammatory bowel disease had higher PSA levels, and were four to five times more likely to develop prostate cancer than those in the control group, the investigators found. The research doesn't show that IBD causes prostate cancer, however, only that the two are linked. Kundu noted that many men with inflamed digestive tracts have elevated PSA levels. He said their doctors shouldn't dismiss those numbers as simply the result of inflammation. "Many doctors think their PSA is elevated just because they have an inflammatory condition," Kundu said in a university news release. For now, however, until more research is underway, "there is no data to guide how we should treat these men," he added. The study was published Dec. 7, 2018 in the journal European Urology.

Posts.Content: After your next MRI, which I trust is a 3T multi-parametric one, consider a fused biopsy. Note that neither an MRI nor PSA can rule out cancer. Posts.Title: Woohoo!

Posts.Content: Golf as a metaphor for PCa or life.....you'll do best when you don't overthink it. Carcinophobia or Fear of Getting Cancer You see it everywhere – articles and news reports that feature experts who talk about how they’ve just discovered that a particular environmental factor causes cancer or that exposure to particular sweeteners or preservatives will give you cancer. Additionally, celebrities keep cancer in the public eye by candidly discussing their cancer diagnoses or treatments in magazines and newspapers across the country. Did you ever get the idea that it is almost impossible to walk out the door without coming in contact with something that’s sure to cause a tumor? Even though it is said jokingly, people often remark that everything causes cancer nowadays. It’s no wonder, then, that people are beginning to fear getting cancer before they even develop it. Carcinophobia, or the fear of getting cancer, typically affects those who have had the disease or have known people afflicted with it. Of course, it’s normal to experience fear of any kind but people with carcinophobia often take their fear to the extreme and when that fear impacts their everyday life it becomes a source for concern. Of all the phobias that exist, the fear of getting cancer can be one of the most debilitating. Take a fear of heights in comparison: the person afflicted with this fear can avoid heights and continue about their day. But a person who suffers from carcinophobia carries their fear with them. For them, the slightest pain or the appearance of new mole or lump on the body is a guarantee of cancer. What follows is anxiety about everything associated with cancer: the possibility of painful treatments, loss of hair, spreading of the cancer, and death. They’re also bound to worry about how it will impact their personal lives. Who will take care of them while they’re sick? Who will take care of their family and children if they succumb to the disease? These concerns and many others often arise before they’ve even visited a doctor. Eventually, the fear can become so overwhelming that the person may refuse to leave their safe environment and may shun people because they might be “carrying” carcinogens. The good news is that this fear of getting cancer, like any other phobia, is treatable. Like most things, we often fear what we don’t understand and it can be helpful for the person who is afraid of getting cancer to research the latest advancements in cancer treatment technologies. Cognitive behavioral therapy can help the person become aware of their unreasonable thoughts and fears so they can view the situation more realistically and react in a healthier way. If all else fails, psychological counseling combined with the use of anxiety disorders medications has shown great results in many people. If you or someone you know suffers from a fear of getting cancer, please seek professional help before it impacts your life. Left untreated, carcinophobia can become a debilitating condition that can affect every aspect of the sufferer’s work, social, and home life. For more information on carcinophobia and treatment for the fear of getting cancer, contact Dr. Andrew Rosen and The Center for Treatment of Anxiety and Mood Disorders in Delray Beach, Florida. They can be reached by calling 561-496-1094 or by emailing Dr. Rosen and The Center today.

Posts.Title: 12 years

Posts.Content: I've spent time at both the NCI in Bethesda, and at Johns Hopkins. World class physicians at both. You are most fortunate to have them nearby. I don't know of Dr. Pinto, but if he's at NCI, you can count on him being first class. Find out how many surgeries he has done as lead doctor. Most of the physicians at NCI are primarily researchers rather than clinicians in my experience. Partin, Allaf, Carter, and Pavlovich at John Hopkins are all brilliant, and while they aren't the 'most' experienced surgeons you will find, you wont go wrong with any of them, and yes, I've met with three and spoken to all four. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Good info above. Here is another informative and current article about BCR and Axumin scans. https://www.prostateoncology.com/201...e-with-axumin/ Interestingly it says: <<<The Axumin PET scan, which was approved by the FDA in 2017, is the newest and possibly biggest game-changer for men with PSA relapse since the approval of PSA screening itself. For the first time we have a commercially-available scan that can detect the location of the cancer outside the prostate at a much earlier stage than what was possible with standard bone scans and CT scans. Axumin can detect the cancer’s location while PSA is in the one to five range, rather than in the 10 to 30 range.>>> Clearly not where cog6 is at...thankfully.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Re "[I][COLOR="#0000FF"]Rating surgeons based on results can be problematic.... Also, as patients and consumers, we tend to gravitate towards the MDs who have good personalities and bedside manner. I want the surgeon with the best operative talents and experience regardless of demeanor. The patient is never engaged in friendly conversation with their surgeon during RP! Any rating system is better than none. We have very little true data to make our selection upon. Excellent point!! Very common, and a mistake IMO, to pick a surgeon on personality.

Posts.Content: How very interesting. Thanks for posting the article, George. The scientists at Johns Hopkins do amazing work. It's research like this that will result in major improvements for the treatment of all cancers. "Many researchers study only cancer cell growth or its spread, and don't communicate with each other often." In my observation, sadly a common issue slowing down the discovery process. Just gotta hope for the best.

Posts.Title: oh life sucks

Posts.Content: Lots of good information in the stickies, above. Since originality is just undiscovered plagiarism, I'm including an extensive list from my friend, Nick. Only item I'd add is buy an abdominal binder on Amazon for about $15. It helps with post surgery discomfort: PRE-SURGERY: • One thing I forgot to do is make sure everyone touching me in the OR would be In Network with my insurance plan. I’ve read a lot of articles about this problem and hopefully will not receive any surprise bills. • I suggest renting a recliner. Oh boy, do I wish I did that! I don’t care how big and ugly it looks. I had made a wedge of pillows for my bed but it is not the same thing. With a cath the bed was hard and painful to get in and out of! I should have used a home healthcare company and got one with an electric lift mechanism. • I had only 12 days between my decision day and surgery, had I had more I would have worked on my core as has been suggested here. So start doing core strengthening to help with your recovery. • If you are single you should consider hiring a healthcare aide for five days. It’s a lot of work to ask of a friend. My wife did a great job of caring for me, I can’t imaging coming home to an empty place. • Buy a Grabber! As Seen On TV. You won’t want to bend over much after surgery. • Lay out carpet runners and big old towels between your bed and the toilet. Lots of dripping for a few days. • It would not hurt if a couple of days prior you went on a very light, easy to digest, plant based diet. You will be looking forward to your first post op BM and it will be easier if it wasn’t a steak dinner! • I had pre-positioned a folding table parallel to my bed so everything was within in reach, there’s lots of meds to take and you need to keep a log of their schedule. Do as much of this as you can before you leave for surgery. • Buy a blindfold so you can nap with the sun coming into your room. • Have a good thermometer on hand. I had some fever for a few days. • Have all the chargers you need laid out with extension cords so your electronics are within reach of your bed or recliner. • Buy a case of bottled water. Strategically place them around your path. • Buy some Pressure Socks. I had a pair from my international travel days and the hospital didn’t give out any, so if you have those you can sleep better at night not worrying about blood clots. • I took a 4’x4’ piece of painter’s plastic drop cloth and laid it between the mattress and sheet, just in case the pad didn’t get absorb any accidents. • Buy lots of continence supplies and keep your receipt to return what you don’t use. I bought lots of Depend type products but those pads don’t absorb much . I have been using small washcloths which are a lot more absorbent and washable. • At the medical supply store buy a spare cath tube anchor for your other leg, or ask the hospital for one upon discharge. If they give you only one it can lose its stickiness. • Buy a bottle of Milk of Magnesia just in case you need it when you get home. I did. The prescription stool softener wasn’t powerful enough. • Have bathrobes on hand. A bathrobe will have a pocket for your phone. I went through several a day because of leakage. We did a lot of laundry. Those “pads”…they aren’t very absorbent, they’re for drips. • If possible, I’d have stayed two days. Sure, I was “able” to leave by noon the next day but I wasn’t really prepared for the headache of a tube sticking out and yanking Mr. Midnight. Ugh. So arrange this possibility. • Bring earplugs! I was in a very new, high tech private hospital room and there were so many machines and gizmos, clicking, beeping, hissing, etc. I had to twist kleenex into ear plugs in order to sleep. • Have some double bagged paper grocery bags with handles ready, so you can walk with your cath. • I was zonked for a good 5 days after surgery, so don’t assume you can do high cognitive functioning. Pay your bills, balance your checkbook, etc. Today is Post Op Day 7 and I started contacting clients just now. That’s how difficult my recovery was. • Leave very early for your surgery day so you don’t stress with the traffic and parking. It’s traumatic enough. Surgery day is different than all your previous consult days. You’re no longer dealing with the friendly folks in the Urology department, suddenly you’re the patient of a very efficient, fast moving, no nonsense surgical department, which feels like the heart of the hospital, and they are a very serious bunch. So don’t be late! • Naively, I had planned to do a lot of reading and Netflix watching in my recovery, but you can’t sit still for very long, you need to walk a lot. My attention span was fuzzy and short. • If you don’t already have one, buy a plastic stool for your shower. The highlight of your day will be two hot showers, and with a cath it’s hard to stand. • If you have a pair of crutches, put one in the shower so you can get up from your stool, and the other for your bedside. With one hand you’re holding the cath tube so you really have only one arm to get out of bed or up from your stool, the crutch will help. • Buy a lot of easy to digest food ahead of time. They’ll tell you that you can eat what you want, but it will be less painful to have a BM if you ate a very light, plant based diet. • Place large plastic waste bins in your bedroom and bathroom. You’ll be making a lot of wet diapers! POST SURGERY: • My operation went “picture perfect” I was told. The problems occurred when I got home, mainly the cath bothered me and my balls swelled up into one painful cantaloupe! So I was not very mobile and had to rely on the pain killers more than I wanted to. • When they prep you for discharge they will give you lots of instructions and you won’t be able to take notes fast enough. They’ll say don’t worry, they’ll give you instructions. Forget that! Never enough. Record them on your cell phone so you can play back later. We played back their tutorials many times. • If you don’t have a big recliner and will use a bed to sleep, make a large wedge of pillows so your butt is higher than the edge of the bed where the cath tube goes over to the bag, so gravity will work properly. Halfway through the night make sure the bag isn’t too full! Use a plastic bucket for the bag. • What made my recovery so miserable, besides the cath, was my balls swelled up and I needed to ice them down with a bag. Quite common they said, so have an ice bag ready. Well, that's all I can remember for now. I watched on YouTube "Mark's Prostate Cancer Experience".

Surgery day is different than all your previous consult days. You’re no longer dealing with the friendly folks in the Urology department, suddenly you’re the patient of a very efficient, fast moving, no nonsense surgical department, which feels like the heart of the hospital, and they are a very serious bunch. So don’t be late! • Naively, I had planned to do a lot of reading and Netflix watching in my recovery, but you can’t sit still for very long, you need to walk a lot. My attention span was fuzzy and short. • If you don’t already have one, buy a plastic stool for your shower. The highlight of your day will be two hot showers, and with a cath it’s hard to stand. • If you have a pair of crutches, put one in the shower so you can get up from your stool, and the other for your bedside. With one hand you’re holding the cath tube so you really have only one arm to get out of bed or up from your stool, the crutch will help. • Buy a lot of easy to digest food ahead of time. They’ll tell you that you can eat what you want, but it will be less painful to have a BM if you ate a very light, plant based diet. • Place large plastic waste bins in your bedroom and bathroom. You’ll be making a lot of wet diapers! POST SURGERY: • My operation went “picture perfect” I was told. The problems occurred when I got home, mainly the cath bothered me and my balls swelled up into one painful cantaloupe! So I was not very mobile and had to rely on the pain killers more than I wanted to. • When they prep you for discharge they will give you lots of instructions and you won’t be able to take notes fast enough. They’ll say don’t worry, they’ll give you instructions. Forget that! Never enough. Record them on your cell phone so you can play back later. We played back their tutorials many times. • If you don’t have a big recliner and will use a bed to sleep, make a large wedge of pillows so your butt is higher than the edge of the bed where the cath tube goes over to the bag, so gravity will work properly. Halfway through the night make sure the bag isn’t too full! Use a plastic bucket for the bag. • What made my recovery so miserable, besides the cath, was my balls swelled up and I needed to ice them down with a bag. Quite common they said, so have an ice bag ready. Well, that's all I can remember for now. I watched on YouTube "Mark's Prostate Cancer Experience".

Posts.Content: Lots of good information in the stickies, above. Since originality is just undiscovered plagiarism, I'm including an extensive list from my friend, Nick. Only item I'd add is buy an abdominal binder on Amazon for about $15. It helps with post surgery discomfort: PRE-SURGERY: • One thing I forgot to do is make sure everyone touching me in the OR would be In Network with my insurance plan. I’ve read a lot of articles about this problem and hopefully will not receive any surprise bills. • I suggest renting a recliner. Oh boy, do I wish I did that! I don’t care how big and ugly it looks. I had made a wedge of pillows for my bed but it is not the same thing. With a cath the bed was hard and painful to get in and out of! I should have used a home healthcare company and got one with an electric lift mechanism. • I had only 12 days between my decision day and surgery, had I had more I would have worked on my core as has been suggested here. So start doing core strengthening to help with your recovery. • If you are single you should consider hiring a healthcare aide for five days. It’s a lot of work to ask of a friend. My wife did a great job of caring for me, I can’t imaging coming home to an empty place. • Buy a Grabber! As Seen On TV. You won’t want to bend over much after surgery. • Lay out carpet runners and big old towels between your bed and the toilet. Lots of dripping for a few days. • It would not hurt if a couple of days prior you went on a very light, easy to digest, plant based diet. You will be looking forward to your first post op BM and it will be easier if it wasn’t a steak dinner! • I had pre-positioned a folding table parallel to my bed so everything was within in reach, there’s lots of meds to take and you need to keep a log of their schedule. Do as much of this as you can before you leave for surgery. • Buy a blindfold so you can nap with the sun coming into your room. • Have a good thermometer on hand. I had some fever for a few days. • Have all the chargers you need laid out with extension cords so your electronics are within reach of your bed or recliner. • Buy a case of bottled water. Strategically place them around your path. • Buy some Pressure Socks. I had a pair from my international travel days and the hospital didn’t give out any, so if you have those you can sleep better at night not worrying about blood clots. • I took a 4’x4’ piece of painter’s plastic drop cloth and laid it between the mattress and sheet, just in case the pad didn’t get absorb any accidents. • Buy lots of continence supplies and keep your receipt to return what you don’t use. I bought lots of Depend type products but those pads don’t absorb much . I have been using small washcloths which are a lot more absorbent and washable. • At the medical supply store buy a spare cath tube anchor for your other leg, or ask the hospital for one upon discharge. If they give you only one it can lose its stickiness. • Buy a bottle of Milk of Magnesia just in case you need it when you get home. I did. The prescription stool softener wasn’t powerful enough. • Have bathrobes on hand. A bathrobe will have a pocket for your phone. I went through several a day because of leakage. We did a lot of laundry. Those “pads”…they aren’t very absorbent, they’re for drips. • If possible, I’d have stayed two days. Sure, I was “able” to leave by noon the next day but I wasn’t really prepared for the headache of a tube sticking out and yanking Mr. Midnight. Ugh. So arrange this possibility. • Bring earplugs! I was in a very new, high tech private hospital room and there were so many machines and gizmos, clicking, beeping, hissing, etc. I had to twist kleenex into ear plugs in order to sleep. • Have some double bagged paper grocery bags with handles ready, so you can walk with your cath. • I was zonked for a good 5 days after surgery, so don’t assume you can do high cognitive functioning. Pay your bills, balance your checkbook, etc. Today is Post Op Day 7 and I started contacting clients just now. That’s how difficult my recovery was. • Leave very early for your surgery day so you don’t stress with the traffic and parking. It’s traumatic enough. Surgery day is different than all your previous consult days. You’re no longer dealing with the friendly folks in the Urology department, suddenly you’re the patient of a very efficient, fast moving, no nonsense surgical department, which feels like the heart of the hospital, and they are a very serious bunch. So don’t be late! • Naively, I had planned to do a lot of reading and Netflix watching in my recovery, but you can’t sit still for very long, you need to walk a lot. My attention span was fuzzy and short. • If you don’t already have one, buy a plastic stool for your shower. The highlight of your day will be two hot showers, and with a cath it’s hard to stand. • If you have a pair of crutches, put one in the shower so you can get up from your stool, and the other for your bedside. With one hand you’re holding the cath tube so you really have only one arm to get out of bed or up from your stool, the crutch will help. • Buy a lot of easy to digest food ahead of time. They’ll tell you that you can eat what you want, but it will be less painful to have a BM if you ate a very light, plant based diet. • Place large plastic waste bins in your bedroom and bathroom. You’ll be making a lot of wet diapers! POST SURGERY: • My operation went “picture perfect” I was told. The problems occurred when I got home, mainly the cath bothered me and my balls swelled up into one painful cantaloupe! So I was not very mobile and had to rely on the pain killers more than I wanted to. • When they prep you for discharge they will give you lots of instructions and you won’t be able to take notes fast enough. They’ll say don’t worry, they’ll give you instructions. Forget that! Never enough. Record them on your cell phone so you can play back later. We played back their tutorials many times. • If you don’t have a big recliner and will use a bed to sleep, make a large wedge of pillows so your butt is higher than the edge of the bed where the cath tube goes over to the bag, so gravity will work properly. Halfway through the night make sure the bag isn’t too full! Use a plastic bucket for the bag. • What made my recovery so miserable, besides the cath, was my balls swelled up and I needed to ice them down with a bag. Quite common they said, so have an ice bag ready. Well, that's all I can remember for now. I watched on YouTube "Mark's Prostate Cancer Experience".

Posts.Content: My friend, MF, has his usual compassionate evaluation. Serge....you have obviously done a fair amount of research. The book you refer to was published over a year ago, the author isn't a well known researcher as far as I know, and I suspect you're giving the book more attention than it probably deserves. Much as all of us would like, there are no silver bullets, or easy cures, with PCa. I suggest you balance the stories in this book with some other more scientific data from the sticky of prostate publications, at the top of the page.

Posts.Content: That Rob, is one of the few rational explanations I've read about the need for extending HT. The issue of how much HT assists post active radiation in killing cancer cells is open for much debate. Given your pathology, 18 months seems a very reasonable call. Speak to you very soon!

My wife did a great job of caring for me, I can’t imaging coming home to an empty place. • Buy a Grabber! As Seen On TV. You won’t want to bend over much after surgery. • Lay out carpet runners and big old towels between your bed and the toilet. Lots of dripping for a few days. • It would not hurt if a couple of days prior you went on a very light, easy to digest, plant based diet. You will be looking forward to your first post op BM and it will be easier if it wasn’t a steak dinner! • I had pre-positioned a folding table parallel to my bed so everything was within in reach, there’s lots of meds to take and you need to keep a log of their schedule. Do as much of this as you can before you leave for surgery. • Buy a blindfold so you can nap with the sun coming into your room. • Have a good thermometer on hand. I had some fever for a few days. • Have all the chargers you need laid out with extension cords so your electronics are within reach of your bed or recliner. • Buy a case of bottled water. Strategically place them around your path. • Buy some Pressure Socks. I had a pair from my international travel days and the hospital didn’t give out any, so if you have those you can sleep better at night not worrying about blood clots. • I took a 4’x4’ piece of painter’s plastic drop cloth and laid it between the mattress and sheet, just in case the pad didn’t get absorb any accidents. • Buy lots of continence supplies and keep your receipt to return what you don’t use. I bought lots of Depend type products but those pads don’t absorb much . I have been using small washcloths which are a lot more absorbent and washable. • At the medical supply store buy a spare cath tube anchor for your other leg, or ask the hospital for one upon discharge. If they give you only one it can lose its stickiness. • Buy a bottle of Milk of Magnesia just in case you need it when you get home. I did. The prescription stool softener wasn’t powerful enough. • Have bathrobes on hand. A bathrobe will have a pocket for your phone. I went through several a day because of leakage. We did a lot of laundry. Those “pads”…they aren’t very absorbent, they’re for drips. • If possible, I’d have stayed two days. Sure, I was “able” to leave by noon the next day but I wasn’t really prepared for the headache of a tube sticking out and yanking Mr. Midnight. Ugh. So arrange this possibility. • Bring earplugs! I was in a very new, high tech private hospital room and there were so many machines and gizmos, clicking, beeping, hissing, etc. I had to twist kleenex into ear plugs in order to sleep. • Have some double bagged paper grocery bags with handles ready, so you can walk with your cath. • I was zonked for a good 5 days after surgery, so don’t assume you can do high cognitive functioning. Pay your bills, balance your checkbook, etc. Today is Post Op Day 7 and I started contacting clients just now. That’s how difficult my recovery was. • Leave very early for your surgery day so you don’t stress with the traffic and parking. It’s traumatic enough. Surgery day is different than all your previous consult days. You’re no longer dealing with the friendly folks in the Urology department, suddenly you’re the patient of a very efficient, fast moving, no nonsense surgical department, which feels like the heart of the hospital, and they are a very serious bunch. So don’t be late! • Naively, I had planned to do a lot of reading and Netflix watching in my recovery, but you can’t sit still for very long, you need to walk a lot. My attention span was fuzzy and short. • If you don’t already have one, buy a plastic stool for your shower. The highlight of your day will be two hot showers, and with a cath it’s hard to stand. • If you have a pair of crutches, put one in the shower so you can get up from your stool, and the other for your bedside. With one hand you’re holding the cath tube so you really have only one arm to get out of bed or up from your stool, the crutch will help. • Buy a lot of easy to digest food ahead of time. They’ll tell you that you can eat what you want, but it will be less painful to have a BM if you ate a very light, plant based diet. • Place large plastic waste bins in your bedroom and bathroom. You’ll be making a lot of wet diapers! POST SURGERY: • My operation went “picture perfect” I was told. The problems occurred when I got home, mainly the cath bothered me and my balls swelled up into one painful cantaloupe! So I was not very mobile and had to rely on the pain killers more than I wanted to. • When they prep you for discharge they will give you lots of instructions and you won’t be able to take notes fast enough. They’ll say don’t worry, they’ll give you instructions. Forget that! Never enough. Record them on your cell phone so you can play back later. We played back their tutorials many times. • If you don’t have a big recliner and will use a bed to sleep, make a large wedge of pillows so your butt is higher than the edge of the bed where the cath tube goes over to the bag, so gravity will work properly. Halfway through the night make sure the bag isn’t too full! Use a plastic bucket for the bag. • What made my recovery so miserable, besides the cath, was my balls swelled up and I needed to ice them down with a bag. Quite common they said, so have an ice bag ready. Well, that's all I can remember for now. I watched on YouTube "Mark's Prostate Cancer Experience".

Posts.Title: Robotic prostatectomy in two days - Some questions

Posts.Content: Some things may be average, but nothing is 'normal' with this maddening disease, and your side effects micro management and frustration is only exacerbating the situation, in my experience. Walk, exercise, Kegal, try not obsessing about every detail this early in the game, and start enjoying life and counting your blessings. Like sailing on the wind, it's unpredictable, but you're doing well so far. Good luck, sailor.

Posts.Content: Emar....it all sounds good. Get, and study, that book. PSA is a strange dynamic. Unlike your husband, mine have always been low but my biopsey was much more alarming than the last one your husband had. You're in very good hands with a second option at Johns Hopkins. I can only image the angst the two of you have been going through. Learn as much as you can, decide on a course of action, and get it done. He will be fine. Good luck!

Best of luck for a speedy recovery and a good path report.
