Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: Lots of good information in the stickies, above. Since originality is just undiscovered plagiarism, I'm including an extensive list from my friend, Nick. Only item I'd add is buy an abdominal binder on Amazon for about $15. It helps with post surgery discomfort: PRE-SURGERY: • One thing I forgot to do is make sure everyone touching me in the OR would be In Network with my insurance plan. I’ve read a lot of articles about this problem and hopefully will not receive any surprise bills. • I suggest renting a recliner. Oh boy, do I wish I did that! I don’t care how big and ugly it looks. I had made a wedge of pillows for my bed but it is not the same thing. With a cath the bed was hard and painful to get in and out of! I should have used a home healthcare company and got one with an electric lift mechanism. • I had only 12 days between my decision day and surgery, had I had more I would have worked on my core as has been suggested here. So start doing core strengthening to help with your recovery. • If you are single you should consider hiring a healthcare aide for five days. It’s a lot of work to ask of a friend. My wife did a great job of caring for me, I can’t imaging coming home to an empty place. • Buy a Grabber! As Seen On TV. You won’t want to bend over much after surgery. • Lay out carpet runners and big old towels between your bed and the toilet. Lots of dripping for a few days. • It would not hurt if a couple of days prior you went on a very light, easy to digest, plant based diet. You will be looking forward to your first post op BM and it will be easier if it wasn’t a steak dinner! • I had pre-positioned a folding table parallel to my bed so everything was within in reach, there’s lots of meds to take and you need to keep a log of their schedule. Do as much of this as you can before you leave for surgery. • Buy a blindfold so you can nap with the sun coming into your room. • Have a good thermometer on hand. I had some fever for a few days. • Have all the chargers you need laid out with extension cords so your electronics are within reach of your bed or recliner. • Buy a case of bottled water. Strategically place them around your path. • Buy some Pressure Socks. I had a pair from my international travel days and the hospital didn’t give out any, so if you have those you can sleep better at night not worrying about blood clots. • I took a 4’x4’ piece of painter’s plastic drop cloth and laid it between the mattress and sheet, just in case the pad didn’t get absorb any accidents. • Buy lots of continence supplies and keep your receipt to return what you don’t use. I bought lots of Depend type products but those pads don’t absorb much . I have been using small washcloths which are a lot more absorbent and washable. • At the medical supply store buy a spare cath tube anchor for your other leg, or ask the hospital for one upon discharge. If they give you only one it can lose its stickiness. • Buy a bottle of Milk of Magnesia just in case you need it when you get home. I did. The prescription stool softener wasn’t powerful enough. • Have bathrobes on hand. A bathrobe will have a pocket for your phone. I went through several a day because of leakage. We did a lot of laundry. Those “pads”…they aren’t very absorbent, they’re for drips. • If possible, I’d have stayed two days. Sure, I was “able” to leave by noon the next day but I wasn’t really prepared for the headache of a tube sticking out and yanking Mr. Midnight. Ugh. So arrange this possibility. • Bring earplugs! I was in a very new, high tech private hospital room and there were so many machines and gizmos, clicking, beeping, hissing, etc. I had to twist kleenex into ear plugs in order to sleep. • Have some double bagged paper grocery bags with handles ready, so you can walk with your cath. • I was zonked for a good 5 days after surgery, so don’t assume you can do high cognitive functioning. Pay your bills, balance your checkbook, etc. Today is Post Op Day 7 and I started contacting clients just now. That’s how difficult my recovery was. • Leave very early for your surgery day so you don’t stress with the traffic and parking. It’s traumatic enough. Surgery day is different than all your previous consult days. You’re no longer dealing with the friendly folks in the Urology department, suddenly you’re the patient of a very efficient, fast moving, no nonsense surgical department, which feels like the heart of the hospital, and they are a very serious bunch. So don’t be late! • Naively, I had planned to do a lot of reading and Netflix watching in my recovery, but you can’t sit still for very long, you need to walk a lot. My attention span was fuzzy and short. • If you don’t already have one, buy a plastic stool for your shower. The highlight of your day will be two hot showers, and with a cath it’s hard to stand. • If you have a pair of crutches, put one in the shower so you can get up from your stool, and the other for your bedside. With one hand you’re holding the cath tube so you really have only one arm to get out of bed or up from your stool, the crutch will help. • Buy a lot of easy to digest food ahead of time. They’ll tell you that you can eat what you want, but it will be less painful to have a BM if you ate a very light, plant based diet. • Place large plastic waste bins in your bedroom and bathroom. You’ll be making a lot of wet diapers! POST SURGERY: • My operation went “picture perfect” I was told. The problems occurred when I got home, mainly the cath bothered me and my balls swelled up into one painful cantaloupe! So I was not very mobile and had to rely on the pain killers more than I wanted to. • When they prep you for discharge they will give you lots of instructions and you won’t be able to take notes fast enough. They’ll say don’t worry, they’ll give you instructions. Forget that! Never enough. Record them on your cell phone so you can play back later. We played back their tutorials many times. • If you don’t have a big recliner and will use a bed to sleep, make a large wedge of pillows so your butt is higher than the edge of the bed where the cath tube goes over to the bag, so gravity will work properly. Halfway through the night make sure the bag isn’t too full! Use a plastic bucket for the bag. • What made my recovery so miserable, besides the cath, was my balls swelled up and I needed to ice them down with a bag. Quite common they said, so have an ice bag ready. Well, that's all I can remember for now. I watched on YouTube "Mark's Prostate Cancer Experience".

We played back their tutorials many times. • If you don’t have a big recliner and will use a bed to sleep, make a large wedge of pillows so your butt is higher than the edge of the bed where the cath tube goes over to the bag, so gravity will work properly. Halfway through the night make sure the bag isn’t too full! Use a plastic bucket for the bag. • What made my recovery so miserable, besides the cath, was my balls swelled up and I needed to ice them down with a bag. Quite common they said, so have an ice bag ready. Well, that's all I can remember for now. I watched on YouTube "Mark's Prostate Cancer Experience".

Posts.Title: 1 year PSA counting down!

Posts.Content: Lots of good information in the stickies, above. Since originality is just undiscovered plagiarism, I'm including an extensive list from my friend, Nick. Only item I'd add is buy an abdominal binder on Amazon for about $15. It helps with post surgery discomfort: PRE-SURGERY: • One thing I forgot to do is make sure everyone touching me in the OR would be In Network with my insurance plan. I’ve read a lot of articles about this problem and hopefully will not receive any surprise bills. • I suggest renting a recliner. Oh boy, do I wish I did that! I don’t care how big and ugly it looks. I had made a wedge of pillows for my bed but it is not the same thing. With a cath the bed was hard and painful to get in and out of! I should have used a home healthcare company and got one with an electric lift mechanism. • I had only 12 days between my decision day and surgery, had I had more I would have worked on my core as has been suggested here. So start doing core strengthening to help with your recovery. • If you are single you should consider hiring a healthcare aide for five days. It’s a lot of work to ask of a friend. My wife did a great job of caring for me, I can’t imaging coming home to an empty place. • Buy a Grabber! As Seen On TV. You won’t want to bend over much after surgery. • Lay out carpet runners and big old towels between your bed and the toilet. Lots of dripping for a few days. • It would not hurt if a couple of days prior you went on a very light, easy to digest, plant based diet. You will be looking forward to your first post op BM and it will be easier if it wasn’t a steak dinner! • I had pre-positioned a folding table parallel to my bed so everything was within in reach, there’s lots of meds to take and you need to keep a log of their schedule. Do as much of this as you can before you leave for surgery. • Buy a blindfold so you can nap with the sun coming into your room. • Have a good thermometer on hand. I had some fever for a few days. • Have all the chargers you need laid out with extension cords so your electronics are within reach of your bed or recliner. • Buy a case of bottled water. Strategically place them around your path. • Buy some Pressure Socks. I had a pair from my international travel days and the hospital didn’t give out any, so if you have those you can sleep better at night not worrying about blood clots. • I took a 4’x4’ piece of painter’s plastic drop cloth and laid it between the mattress and sheet, just in case the pad didn’t get absorb any accidents. • Buy lots of continence supplies and keep your receipt to return what you don’t use. I bought lots of Depend type products but those pads don’t absorb much . I have been using small washcloths which are a lot more absorbent and washable. • At the medical supply store buy a spare cath tube anchor for your other leg, or ask the hospital for one upon discharge. If they give you only one it can lose its stickiness. • Buy a bottle of Milk of Magnesia just in case you need it when you get home. I did. The prescription stool softener wasn’t powerful enough. • Have bathrobes on hand. A bathrobe will have a pocket for your phone. I went through several a day because of leakage. We did a lot of laundry. Those “pads”…they aren’t very absorbent, they’re for drips. • If possible, I’d have stayed two days. Sure, I was “able” to leave by noon the next day but I wasn’t really prepared for the headache of a tube sticking out and yanking Mr. Midnight. Ugh. So arrange this possibility. • Bring earplugs! I was in a very new, high tech private hospital room and there were so many machines and gizmos, clicking, beeping, hissing, etc. I had to twist kleenex into ear plugs in order to sleep. • Have some double bagged paper grocery bags with handles ready, so you can walk with your cath. • I was zonked for a good 5 days after surgery, so don’t assume you can do high cognitive functioning. Pay your bills, balance your checkbook, etc. Today is Post Op Day 7 and I started contacting clients just now. That’s how difficult my recovery was. • Leave very early for your surgery day so you don’t stress with the traffic and parking. It’s traumatic enough. Surgery day is different than all your previous consult days. You’re no longer dealing with the friendly folks in the Urology department, suddenly you’re the patient of a very efficient, fast moving, no nonsense surgical department, which feels like the heart of the hospital, and they are a very serious bunch. So don’t be late! • Naively, I had planned to do a lot of reading and Netflix watching in my recovery, but you can’t sit still for very long, you need to walk a lot. My attention span was fuzzy and short. • If you don’t already have one, buy a plastic stool for your shower. The highlight of your day will be two hot showers, and with a cath it’s hard to stand. • If you have a pair of crutches, put one in the shower so you can get up from your stool, and the other for your bedside. With one hand you’re holding the cath tube so you really have only one arm to get out of bed or up from your stool, the crutch will help. • Buy a lot of easy to digest food ahead of time. They’ll tell you that you can eat what you want, but it will be less painful to have a BM if you ate a very light, plant based diet. • Place large plastic waste bins in your bedroom and bathroom. You’ll be making a lot of wet diapers! POST SURGERY: • My operation went “picture perfect” I was told. The problems occurred when I got home, mainly the cath bothered me and my balls swelled up into one painful cantaloupe! So I was not very mobile and had to rely on the pain killers more than I wanted to. • When they prep you for discharge they will give you lots of instructions and you won’t be able to take notes fast enough. They’ll say don’t worry, they’ll give you instructions. Forget that! Never enough. Record them on your cell phone so you can play back later. We played back their tutorials many times. • If you don’t have a big recliner and will use a bed to sleep, make a large wedge of pillows so your butt is higher than the edge of the bed where the cath tube goes over to the bag, so gravity will work properly. Halfway through the night make sure the bag isn’t too full! Use a plastic bucket for the bag. • What made my recovery so miserable, besides the cath, was my balls swelled up and I needed to ice them down with a bag. Quite common they said, so have an ice bag ready. Well, that's all I can remember for now. I watched on YouTube "Mark's Prostate Cancer Experience".

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Yes, which is precisely why you should not hesitate and specifically ask the surgeon you are "interviewing" about his/her ED and urinary outcome statistics in addition to surgical-margin percentage and years of experience/number of procedures done. Not just ask, but insist on them! Many surgeons, unfortunately, have glib answers to avoid giving us their specific results. You can be certain they have them. One simple question to ask is, “how do YOU know you’re a successful surgeon?” Their answer should be telling; be ready for some clever BS double-talk.

Posts.Content: Emar....it all sounds good. Get, and study, that book. PSA is a strange dynamic. Unlike your husband, mine have always been low but my biopsey was much more alarming than the last one your husband had. You're in very good hands with a second option at Johns Hopkins. I can only image the angst the two of you have been going through. Learn as much as you can, decide on a course of action, and get it done. He will be fine. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee About a year ago I met Gary for lunch, before he started ADT and RT. He remarked about the waitress. I said she's beautiful, but have not idea what I would do with her. He questioned my remark. Now he knows. A fine lunch and a cute waitress, Rob. I remember the conversation well. I guess we're all different. When my T went to 3, from 660, physical excitement went with it, but mental stirrings were never lost. I could still dream about IT My T is at about 300, now, ED is minimal, and penetration is OK. I won't get into radiation proctitis issues. Hang in there, guys!

Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: No need to panic, m2t. His numbers look very good. Here is exactly what the famed Dr. Jon Epstein told me yesterday about recurrent PC: "IF YOU HAD 2 VALUES OVER 0.2 NG/ML" I'm sure he was talking about consecutive readings. Your concern is partially do to the uPSA picking up miniscule variations. RELAX

Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Theraputic Cialis made a noticeable difference for me. 5mg 2 - 3 times a week. It flushes blood through the site and aids healing and recovery. It is important to not take it daily so it surges. Similar to ice and heat therapy on a muscle injury. The alternating heat and cold expands and contracts the blood flow pumping blood through the site. Sounds reasonable, Another. Do you have a source for that advise? The reason I ask is because I've been on 5mg of Cialis daily for the past two months, have been having some morning erections, and actually had the opportunity to use one yesterday. I'm five weeks past surgery.

Posts.Title: Lupron and libido

Posts.Content: Confounding to be sure. I’ve discussed this study with my Daner Farber and Cleveland Clinic RO’s. Given my low intermediate risk category, but rapidly escalating post surgery persistent PSA, both strongly had a recommendation for RT....one said ADT, the other said no ADT. I very reluctantly went with Casodex and Lupron. Time will tell. “Conversely, in men with less aggressive disease (ie, organ confined disease and pathologic grade groups 1–3), PSA level did not impact cancer-specific survival. In these cases, PSA persistence might be a proxy of benign prostatic tissue left behind during RP, and the impact of competing causes of death would thereby be more pronounced. Further, these patients did not demonstrate a benefit from postoperative RT.”

Based on my experience, speed is of the essence. Good luck

Posts.Content: Confounding to be sure. I’ve discussed this study with my Daner Farber and Cleveland Clinic RO’s. Given my low intermediate risk category, but rapidly escalating post surgery persistent PSA, both strongly had a recommendation for RT....one said ADT, the other said no ADT. I very reluctantly went with Casodex and Lupron. Time will tell. “Conversely, in men with less aggressive disease (ie, organ confined disease and pathologic grade groups 1–3), PSA level did not impact cancer-specific survival. In these cases, PSA persistence might be a proxy of benign prostatic tissue left behind during RP, and the impact of competing causes of death would thereby be more pronounced. Further, these patients did not demonstrate a benefit from postoperative RT.”

Posts.Title: Doc says time to do something.

Posts.Content: I have followed your journey for opinions and 'facts' on several forums also, Denis. You have been shaking the tree very hard, and at least to me, have been trying to prove to yourself that AS is a reasonable path. All well and good. I spent over a year doing much the same about AS, and that was without the benefit of being on any forums. If you can be painfully introspective, are you certain that your choice wasn't already made, and all your study hasn't done to just reinforce your initial desire to avoid active treatment? The credo ASA offers, that making choices has three steps, maybe (four): (Research), Decision, Resolution, and Closure, is spot on. My journey, after a year, and I had a little 3+4 also, ended when Dr. Bal Carter at JH, who knows more about AS than you or I ever will, told me I was kidding myself about staying on AS. He had a long list of reasons, but it all came down to I would need treatment in the foreseeable future, I was in very good shape now, and if I wanted another 15 or 20 worry free good years why prolong the commitment? Your five years younger that me, but the question is still valid. Do you want to hold off for ten years, when you'll be 75, and maybe in not such good shape? Yes, new discoveries are happening all the time, but they will probably not be proven out over that time period. If you want AS, go for it, find comfort in the decision, and relax. Just guard against confirmation bias, and best of luck on your journey

Posts.Title: New Forum Member

Posts.Content: I've been reading and re-reading this study for several weeks, Jarad. It's most encouraging in my situation. A note of caution for new folks wondering about the relative merits of various bio-markers that can help in treatment decisions. One brother here has repeatedly written that he used Decipher results to decide against AS. This was not a good test for that decision. I researched it extensively a year ago for the same purpose, shared my findings with him, but to no avail. The Prolaris test is better at detecting aggressive cancers than it is at finding low-risk tumors that may not become life threatening for many years. The Genomic Health Oncotype DX test is much the same. It's used to detect the presence of high grade cancer in tissue removed during biopsy or surgery, and the likelihood that that the tumor is confined to the prostate. It's aimed at guys with low to intermediate risk PCa who may be considering AS. The aforementioned Decipher test manufactured by Genome DX Biosciences is utilized to make better decisions about whether to proceed with additional treatment AFTER prostate removal surgery. This from Dr. Marc Garnick, Editor in Chief of the annual Harvard Prostate Disease Report. Many average Uro's don't have a clue about new bio-markers, even, it appears, inexperienced Uro's at Yale.

Posts.Title: The Decipher Test for Predicting Metastasis in Post-RP Patients with Persistent PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis I might be the person you referred to as deciding against AS using Decipher. I respectfully disagree with your assessment. That's not the point Denis, and it isn't MY assessment. The Decipher test, while top notch, isn't an ideal bio-marker for decision making before surgery. There are at least two other tests more specifically designed for that. While bio-markers are only a piece of the decision making process, it behooves our brothers to utilize the best tests and information available. Your anecdotal information, whatever it is, doesn't trump either Dr. Marc Garnick, Editor in Chief of the superb annual Harvard Prostate Disease Report, or this study, by another noted physician: http://ascopubs.org/doi/full/10.1200...source=TrendMD That being said, I'm sure intervention will work out for you, and you have finally come to a reasonable choice. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: The Decipher Test

Posts.Content: I have followed your journey for opinions and 'facts' on several forums also, Denis. You have been shaking the tree very hard, and at least to me, have been trying to prove to yourself that AS is a reasonable path. All well and good. I spent over a year doing much the same about AS, and that was without the benefit of being on any forums. If you can be painfully introspective, are you certain that your choice wasn't already made, and all your study hasn't done to just reinforce your initial desire to avoid active treatment? The credo ASA offers, that making choices has three steps, maybe (four): (Research), Decision, Resolution, and Closure, is spot on. My journey, after a year, and I had a little 3+4 also, ended when Dr. Bal Carter at JH, who knows more about AS than you or I ever will, told me I was kidding myself about staying on AS. He had a long list of reasons, but it all came down to I would need treatment in the foreseeable future, I was in very good shape now, and if I wanted another 15 or 20 worry free good years why prolong the commitment? Your five years younger that me, but the question is still valid. Do you want to hold off for ten years, when you'll be 75, and maybe in not such good shape? Yes, new discoveries are happening all the time, but they will probably not be proven out over that time period. If you want AS, go for it, find comfort in the decision, and relax. Just guard against confirmation bias, and best of luck on your journey

Posts.Title: Is it time to worry?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Here's some info for you, Bad. Years ago, Johns Hopkins conducted a survey of 17,000 TRUE GLEASON 6 patients (meaning post-op pathology confirmed only G6). Out of all 17,000, the total number with metastasis was ZERO. To add to that, I met with noted RO, Dr. Anthony D'Amico at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute two days ago. He said the with a G3+4, metastases is all but unheard of. IMHO, what's even worse than having PCa, is all the uncertainty and unnecessary angst it causes for so many of us.

Posts.Title: The Decipher Test for Predicting Metastasis in Post-RP Patients with Persistent PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis I might be the person you referred to as deciding against AS using Decipher. I respectfully disagree with your assessment. That's not the point Denis, and it isn't MY assessment. The Decipher test, while top notch, isn't an ideal bio-marker for decision making before surgery. There are at least two other tests more specifically designed for that. While bio-markers are only a piece of the decision making process, it behooves our brothers to utilize the best tests and information available. Your anecdotal information, whatever it is, doesn't trump either Dr. Marc Garnick, Editor in Chief of the superb annual Harvard Prostate Disease Report, or this study, by another noted physician: http://ascopubs.org/doi/full/10.1200...source=TrendMD That being said, I'm sure intervention will work out for you, and you have finally come to a reasonable choice. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Welcome....and happy birthday! Get on the phone with your hospital's records and/or pathology department and insist they scan you your pathology report. Then call your surgeon and instruct her or her staff to send your slides to Dr. Epstein at Johns Hopkins for a second pathology opinion. A T4, if you heard her correctly, is not to be taken lightly. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Fredd....it appears you have classic persistent PSA. You need to locate an RO who is familiar with it. Getting your detailed pathology report and a second reading of it will be most valuable. You need to get ahead of whatever is driving that PSA. Ive been told that Australia has CT-PET-PSMA equipment that is much more sensitive that what we have available in the USA. Hopefully an experienced RO can hook you up with it. Based on my experience, speed is of the essence. Good luck

Posts.Content: Welcome to this club nobody really wants to belong to, but glad you found us. I concur with Rob and Chuck. Get the 'bible' by Dr. Walsh, and read it on your drive over to the Mayo Clinic, where world class experts reside. I suspect your urologist may be 'old school' if he only does open surgery, but both it and robotic, in experienced hands, are equal. Best of luck and keep us posted.

Eric I suggest you are a part of that discussion, and that you make certain the RO and MO are well experienced in prostate cancer. A second and even third opinion from a large teaching hospital urology department would seem appropriate. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Continence and penile implant Appt

Posts.Content: Well, MM, you can include me, too. As we all try to help each other, posting dark and morbid ruminations, is neither healthy for Dennis, nor does it send a positive message to new guys just showing up, IMO. Dennis is obviously a nice man, but his many posts over the last year worry me about his emotional health and don't add up, especially given that he professes the be living life to the fullest, being blessed with a life second to none, and having loving family, great friends, good health, fun travels, lots of toys and a keen awareness of the importance of living for today. At the same time, he talks about battling the loneliness of his having cancer, and as Semi pointed out, a very mild case of it at that, which has been very well treated. He has every reason to be rejoicing in his many blessings and singing for joy, each and every day. Instead we read nicely written dispirited meanderings. Of course he has every right to feel the way he does, but if that is obviously unhealthy, we do IMHO, have an obligation to point it out to a fellow brother, and that doesn't make us "insensitive", MM. I feel for him, and I believe he has let cancer "have him". I hope he can learn to control his depression and, as he said so well, "choose to be alive and thrive". From the bottom of my heart...best of luck beating the mental challenges this maddening disease can bring on, Dennis.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm ....Then comes the balloon in the butt part. This wasn't near as bad as I thought it would be, even when she filled it with 60cc of water. Then I was positioned on the CT sacan table. She did three scans. The second was a confirmation of the first, and the third was with the balloon removed..... Fine report, Mike. Is this being done at the main campus of MDA? That was a most comprehensive simulation, and in my experience was much better than what most of us get. The endorectal balloon you'll receive daily cuts down on the dangers of radiation damage to other organs. Most RT facilities don't use it, primarily I believe, because they don't know how! I sure wish I had the benefit of it, but when requested, all I got was the "not our SOP" excuse. You're in very good hands at MDA.

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Well, MM, you can include me, too. As we all try to help each other, posting dark and morbid ruminations, is neither healthy for Dennis, nor does it send a positive message to new guys just showing up, IMO. Dennis is obviously a nice man, but his many posts over the last year worry me about his emotional health and don't add up, especially given that he professes the be living life to the fullest, being blessed with a life second to none, and having loving family, great friends, good health, fun travels, lots of toys and a keen awareness of the importance of living for today. At the same time, he talks about battling the loneliness of his having cancer, and as Semi pointed out, a very mild case of it at that, which has been very well treated. He has every reason to be rejoicing in his many blessings and singing for joy, each and every day. Instead we read nicely written dispirited meanderings. Of course he has every right to feel the way he does, but if that is obviously unhealthy, we do IMHO, have an obligation to point it out to a fellow brother, and that doesn't make us "insensitive", MM. I feel for him, and I believe he has let cancer "have him". I hope he can learn to control his depression and, as he said so well, "choose to be alive and thrive". From the bottom of my heart...best of luck beating the mental challenges this maddening disease can bring on, Dennis.

Posts.Title: My Proton Adventure

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm ....Then comes the balloon in the butt part. This wasn't near as bad as I thought it would be, even when she filled it with 60cc of water. Then I was positioned on the CT sacan table. She did three scans. The second was a confirmation of the first, and the third was with the balloon removed..... Fine report, Mike. Is this being done at the main campus of MDA? That was a most comprehensive simulation, and in my experience was much better than what most of us get. The endorectal balloon you'll receive daily cuts down on the dangers of radiation damage to other organs. Most RT facilities don't use it, primarily I believe, because they don't know how! I sure wish I had the benefit of it, but when requested, all I got was the "not our SOP" excuse. You're in very good hands at MDA.

Posts.Title: Very aggressive ducta prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Great advise above....it's OK to be confused, but angry is a wasted emotion IMO. Do get a second opinion on both your pathology, and from another urologist and radiation oncologist. As much G3+4 as you have, begs treatment....not AS. Reading the Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer, 4th edition, by Dr Pat Walsh. It will help you understand the situation, and is MUCH more scientific than getting anecdotal stories from people you don't even know. Every journey is individually unique. I think you'll be fine, but do start digging and researching. Good luck.

Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: A life long, 68 year old friend, just spoke to me, really worried about his prostate condition. Why he thinks I'm a PCa expert is anybody's guess. From what I know, his PSA went from 3.3 in 11/2014, to 5.4 in June of this year. His urologist put him on a 7 week course of antibiotics; Cipro and Doxycycline. At the end of the 7 weeks his PSA is up to 7.9. Yes, he has frequent urination, nocturia, and burning. His initial urologist was nothing to brag about. He just had a 3T MRI, which was very difficult tolocate in San Antonio, probably due to him having 'just' Medicare Advantage. $1,300 out of pocket, that he can ill afford, but... Results, as best as I understand them, are Category 5 in the left anterior transition zone, and Category 4 in the peripheral zone from the apex to the mid gradient. No ECE evident. Looks like he has an aggressive cancer. Of course a biopsy is next, most likely followed by treatment. He says he prefers radiation. My guess is SBRT is probably best for him. So any suggestions for really good RO's in San Antonio??? On my quick review I can't find any. MD Anderson takes Medicare Advantage, if I can convince him to go there. Some places I've looked at for him: 1. START in SAT - ? 2. UT SAT - doesn't take Medicare Advantage Aetna 3. MD Anderson - Not convenience, but great and accepts his insurance 4. UT Southwestern - Dallas and Ft. Worth - to be determined. 5. ARA Diagnostic Imaging in Austin - ? 6. Lots of unimpressive SAT Google ads.... Any suggestions, advise and recommendations will be much appreciated, either public or PM. Thanks, in advance!

Posts.Content: Great link, Another. I guess TSA will have to empty my Foley Sweat pants with a strategic opening will work, but are they large enough to hide/contain the larger collection bag, MF? MM...me go overboard and plan too much? Yep! I was giving it a few extra nights on the slim chance there were complications. I'm in good shape but obviously nowhere near as good as you. Doc want me to keep the catheter in until Thursday or Friday, nine or ten days in total. I do think that could increase the chance for infection. I get the impression that all these surgeons want to stick with whatever their specific protocol is, possibly to eliminate variables when analyzing their success rates. Who knows? Keep them coming. Oh, and yes, there is a fine surgeon down here. I just like to make things complicated according to my long suffering wife.

Posts.Title: Anatomy of a Clinical Trial

Posts.Content: A Brit realtor living in CA. Cool.... If it hasn't been mentioned, you may want to have your biopsy slides sent to Johns Hopkins, for a second opinion. Assuming your in good health otherwise, my choice would be surgery. If your surgeon has experience, confidence, integrity and communicates fairly well, you don't need to like him. Do research your radiation options as well. The side effects are about the same. With surgery they come earlier, you know with certainty what was in the tumor and better know what you're up against. With either treatment there is the possibility of cancer reoccurance, but with radiation there is also the increased uncertainty of future side effect complications. At least that was my logic. I'm sure some of my brothers will point out the holes in my thinking. Best of luck with whatever you decide.

Posts.Content: Some good news, some not so good news. So Dave is allowing you to apply bacitryn to the tip...of what? You guys will get through this, and we are here for you. Please call doc's office and request (insist) they send you a complete pathology report immediately, so you can prepare for the meeting with him. Posting it here will help us help you get ready. Something as basic as 4+5 or 5+4 is a major difference. Bone scan and the much discussed PSMA CT PET Scan are a good start, as is finding a good RO. Hang tough and continue playing music.

Posts.Title: Post RALP good/not so good news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ...Talk with your docs about getting a genomics test. As my case shows, high-grade does not necessarily mean high risk of metastases. As long as it looks like the cancer was prostate-contained and there is no evidence of either persistent PSA (or an "essentially-zero" PSA that later begins to climb), there is no reason for RT. As always, very good advise! A Decipher genome test and a second pathology opinion, from Johns Hopkins, are both logical next steps. It should be noted that MF is a VERY old Parrothead

Posts.Title: Post RALP good/not so good news

Posts.Content: A Brit realtor living in CA. Cool.... If it hasn't been mentioned, you may want to have your biopsy slides sent to Johns Hopkins, for a second opinion. Assuming your in good health otherwise, my choice would be surgery. If your surgeon has experience, confidence, integrity and communicates fairly well, you don't need to like him. Do research your radiation options as well. The side effects are about the same. With surgery they come earlier, you know with certainty what was in the tumor and better know what you're up against. With either treatment there is the possibility of cancer reoccurance, but with radiation there is also the increased uncertainty of future side effect complications. At least that was my logic. I'm sure some of my brothers will point out the holes in my thinking. Best of luck with whatever you decide.

Posts.Title: hope for high risk

Posts.Content: Less than ten weeks after surgery, it appears to have failed, even after all looked so well. I have very little leakage, ED symptoms are minimal, G 3+4=7 Grade Group 2, G pattern 4 = 10%, pT2c pN0 pMn/a, carcinoma organ confined in about 15% of the gland, EPE SV LN negative, PNI present, pathology verified by Dr. Epstein at JHMI. I did have one small positive anterior margin 0.1 mm long and limited < 3mm. Only symptoms I've had are increased urination to 8 times a day/night, with some urgency. So two PSA's in the last two weeks, from different labs, both exactly the same. O.32 ng/Ml This isn't biological recurrance...it never un-occured. I've never even heard of a case with such a high PSA two months after what seemed to be successful surgery. Kind of funny, since I've always had low PSA, never going much highter than 3.0...ever. What happened and why?...I don't have a clue. Where do I go from here?...just starting to sort that out. Is it even called ART or SBT? My main concern is that I've had ulcerative colitis for 45 years, and have had Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), a group of clinical symptoms involving my bladder, urethra, urinary sphincter and prostate for about 7 years. I had a TURP for it one and a half years ago that didn't alleviate the problems at all. This is why over a dozen nationally renowned RO's advised against radiation and for surgery. My two most urgent questions are: one, does anyone know of such an immediate surgery failure, and two, what are my best alternative follow up treatment options?? I'd sure appreciate the forums collective wisdom before I meet with my Urosurgeon in two weeks. Thanks, in advance.

Posts.Content: The hunt for the 'best' requires data mere mortals don't have access to, and definitions that are purely subjective for each patient, and his wife. You can't go wrong with UCLA or UCSF. They are both in the top ten per US News & World Report. Go to their websites and read about their physicans. If you have lots of frequent flyer points, like to travel, and stay in hotels for it. The some of the 'best' are in your own backyard. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Anatomy of a Clinical Trial

Posts.Content: If your doc has a patient portal, or the hospital does, you should be able to obtain your complete pathology report well before the 19th. We can help you understand it, and get you ready to ask the right questions ahead of time, so NO surprises. Persistence in getting that report ASAP will help keep your anxiety to a minimum.
Posts.Title: nmguy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 Scheduled to go back to Moffit in early September to meet with head URO of department who does 2 – 3 prostate surgeries a week…maybe that is where the answer lies? Read he is incredibly compassionate and patient and speaks in a way in which you can understand. Also hunting down other doctors who may give phone consultations. Which, again IMO, is the most rational path of action for your father. It's no surprise you're emotionally exhausted, given the many opinions you have asked for on this and several other forums, not to mention the many doctors you have spoken with, long distance, all the while attempting to come up an impossibly steep learning curve, and find a non exsistant perfect treatment and physician. And from what you say, you're still doing the same thing. I note you've had a lot more than 4 opinions! My tough love for you, and my concern for your dad, is that while seeking out information, at some point......enough is enough. Pick a course of action and go with it. I believe what's best for your dad, are the multiple services and expertise at Moffitt, and the sooner the better! As has already been told to you, and in my experiences, many of the best physicians are not particularly good communicators, and can get testy with extended requests for detailed explanations from patients relatives. You should realize by now that there are NO certainties with PCa. "“Learn from history or you're doomed to repeat it.” At long last it's time to help your dad pick an option, and stop all the confusion. I'm praying for both of you.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer doctor

Posts.Content: So, a search didn't turn up much. I'm flying from SoFL to Baltimore on Sunday, June 11 for RALP on the morning of Tuesday, June 13. Figure a day in Johns Hopkins, and three nights in a local hotel, with two full beds, lots of pillows, a low couch, and a kitchenette. Then fly back to SoFL on Saturday, the 17th, with Foley bag in tow. Wheelchair to plane, bulkhead seating, and hopefully an empty seat between me and my wife. Feet up as much as possible, a cushion for my jewel area, loose fitting slacks or maybe shorts, and a nondescript carrying bag for my bag. Friend with a BIG SUV meeting us at the airport. Any tips, cautions or advise from those of you who have been through it, or just considered it? Thanks, in advance.

Posts.Title: Refused HT

Posts.Content: Great link, Another. I guess TSA will have to empty my Foley Sweat pants with a strategic opening will work, but are they large enough to hide/contain the larger collection bag, MF? MM...me go overboard and plan too much? Yep! I was giving it a few extra nights on the slim chance there were complications. I'm in good shape but obviously nowhere near as good as you. Doc want me to keep the catheter in until Thursday or Friday, nine or ten days in total. I do think that could increase the chance for infection. I get the impression that all these surgeons want to stick with whatever their specific protocol is, possibly to eliminate variables when analyzing their success rates. Who knows? Keep them coming. Oh, and yes, there is a fine surgeon down here. I just like to make things complicated according to my long suffering wife.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ...Talk with your docs about getting a genomics test. As my case shows, high-grade does not necessarily mean high risk of metastases. As long as it looks like the cancer was prostate-contained and there is no evidence of either persistent PSA (or an "essentially-zero" PSA that later begins to climb), there is no reason for RT. As always, very good advise! A Decipher genome test and a second pathology opinion, from Johns Hopkins, are both logical next steps. It should be noted that MF is a VERY old Parrothead

Posts.Title: Month 3 PSA Results

Posts.Content: Some good news, some not so good news. So Dave is allowing you to apply bacitryn to the tip...of what? You guys will get through this, and we are here for you. Please call doc's office and request (insist) they send you a complete pathology report immediately, so you can prepare for the meeting with him. Posting it here will help us help you get ready. Something as basic as 4+5 or 5+4 is a major difference. Bone scan and the much discussed PSMA CT PET Scan are a good start, as is finding a good RO. Hang tough and continue playing music.

A multi parametric endorectal coil -- sounds absolutely delightful -- I wonder if you will be able to pick up Sirius Radio with it in. Just thinking about the coil insertion yields a headache so strong, it blocks out Sirius reception. Not only are they covering to cost of the imaging, they also picked up the cost of the airline flight....economy, of course. Rest easy, I'm not expecting even a single scoop of ice cream.....

Posts.Title: Anatomy of a Clinical Trial

Posts.Content: So, a search didn't turn up much. I'm flying from SoFL to Baltimore on Sunday, June 11 for RALP on the morning of Tuesday, June 13. Figure a day in Johns Hopkins, and three nights in a local hotel, with two full beds, lots of pillows, a low couch, and a kitchenette. Then fly back to SoFL on Saturday, the 17th, with Foley bag in tow. Wheelchair to plane, bulkhead seating, and hopefully an empty seat between me and my wife. Feet up as much as possible, a cushion for my jewel area, loose fitting slacks or maybe shorts, and a nondescript carrying bag for my bag. Friend with a BIG SUV meeting us at the airport. Any tips, cautions or advise from those of you who have been through it, or just considered it? Thanks, in advance.

Posts.Title: nmguy

Posts.Content: You confusion is well placed. Have you received a second opinion on your pathology. Johns Hopkins is as good as it gets for this service. If your doc isn’t a radiation oncologist you should find a good one who specializes in prostate cancer ASAP. A first class teaching Hospital close to you perhaps. We are about the same age and I’ve had ulcerative colitis most of my life. Radiation is not to be taken lightly, nor is two years of ADT. IMO, your caution is well placed. Get that second pathology opinion, AND a more specialized radiation opinion quickly. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: The good news is breast cancer treatments have make remarkable strides, his biopsy results are still unknown and if some PCa is found, there are many excellent interventions, and your cat is in a better place. Take a lesson from your husband and chill. All that worry will not help either one of you, and you both have a long journey to go. Keep studying, relax, and keep us informed. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee As others have said above, this is the best prostate cancer forum on the net.....work things out between ourselves and get on with the important things in life. Amen to that, Rob, and with the best moderator! Cancer can be cruel and it helps to have a thick hide getting through it. Coming here for information and advise is what we’re all about, usually with empathetic straight talk when someone is just feeling sorry for their situation. I was the target of the only personal attack post on the locked thread and not wanting to start a war of words, I didn’t reply. This forum is too good for that, and turning your back on the wealth of knowledge here would IMO be a mistake.

Posts.Title: nmguy

Posts.Content: It matters little if you like the surgeon, and 100 is far too few. Do a forum search on Patel for lots of opinions. He is very rushed, two operating rooms simultaneously, uses only PA's to assist, but his count is over 10,000. His office staff is very well trained and Celebration Hospital is very good. Like being at Disney. Has complacency with his revenue drive set in? Who knows. With world class Johns Hopkins and MSK closer by, why screw around with the JV? We customers are given precious few facts or audited statistics to aid us in making these life altering choices.

Posts.Title: AS no longer an option

Posts.Content: Far be it for me to tell another pilot anything, or to agree with a squid, but you have the answers above, jabr. Your next step is a PHI blood test which will give you doc your PSA, and more. Lots of the shade tree physicians know little about the PHI, and nothing about how to interpret it. Posts.Title: Two Year Update

Posts.Content: The definition of standards seems to always be based on a consensus among experts, rather than being an evidence-based process. Not at all unique to the Europeans. It's a valiant step they are taking. There is so much more that can be done now with true transparency of research, accurate reporting of statistics and findings, better training and ongoing education of physicians. They, and we, gotta start somewhere.

This forum is too good for that, and turning your back on the wealth of knowledge here would IMO be a mistake.

Posts.Title: Probable Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Self-pity is rooted in people taking themselves too seriously. ~ Tom Robbins Of all human emotions, perhaps the most useless and destructive is self-pity, and prostate cancer seems to fuel this emotion in some. It's very hard to realize that one is an ongoing self-pitying person in regards to prostate cancer problems. But the realization, although serving as a bitter slap in the face, can help one to embrace the joy of life with a more open-minded, all-accepting attitude. Find it hard to accept a circumstance, like living with prostate cancer in your life? Mull and muse over your problems often? Feel gloomy and depressed sometimes because of what life has dealt you? Feel like a victim? Have an inexplicable craving for the sympathy and condolences of others? Chances are that youre a self-pitying person. What is self-pity? It is an exaggerated sense of pity over ones own life, position or circumstance. Most of us experience self-pity after a diagnosis of prostate cancer, no matter how mild or aggressive it is, and although the self-pity can serve to be a soothing mechanism , many times it can morph into a toxic habit, and sharing the dark thoughts with others can exacerbate the self-pity. When self-pity is made a habit of, it not only impedes the progress we make with slow moving prostate cancer, but it creates self-destructive cycles of self-sabotage. 11 Signs That You're Chronically Self-Pity Self-pity is our worst enemy and if we yield to it, we can never do anything wise in this world. ~ Helen Keller How much of a self-pitying person are you? Well: #1 You find it hard to laugh at life and at yourself. Taking yourself too seriously, and finding it difficult to laugh at your predicament and condition is a tell-tale sign of self-pity. #2 You tend to crave drama. In truth, you might be a Drama King and tend to have a melodramatic streak to you. Usually this stems from extremist types of thinking (e.g. black-and-white, the world is against me, all-or-nothing mindsets). #3 You tend to crave sympathy. Self-pity is so addictive because it gives one the momentary pleasure of being supported, cared for and emotionally pampered. This is a dangerous, highly manipulative way of developing emotional bonds and connections with other people. We've seen it played out here many times. #4 You tend to be an individualist. Self-pity is one of the most effective ways of keeping yourself separate and independent from friends, family and people around you. Not so much from short-term anonymous internet acquaintances. #5 You tend to be a past-orientated person. Some people live in the present, others in the future, and still others in the past. Self-pity is inextricably linked to past-focused mindsets that dwell on past events. Why did this happen to me? #6 You have low self-esteem. People with low self-esteem tend to crave the acceptance and affection of other people as a way of feeling better about themselves. The tragic-life-story that self-pitying creates is an excellent way of collecting flocks of supporters. #7 You have a melancholic temperament. Melancholic, sanguine, choleric and phlegmatic temperaments are given to bouts of brooding and deep introspection, which can serve as a perfect breeding ground for self-pity. #8 Deep down, you dont believe youre worthy of love. This stems from low self-esteem and creates a cycle of self-destructive behavior. Self-pity is one of the greatest tools for the self-destructive person. It creates self-fulfilling prophecies and alienates the people you love and admire from you. So only sharing the feelings with anonymous web acquaintances seems safe, but is less than courageous, and can fuel insecurities for others. #9 You have an unhealthy habit of being self-absorbed. Quite simply, the more self-absorbed you are, the more likely you are to fall into the trap of self-pity. #10 You have a strong fighting instinct. This can be a good thing or a bad thing, depending on what you choose to use it for. When used in a negative sense, the fighting instinct is used to battle against life, to fight against the tide, and to fight against accepting reality. #11 You subconsciously feel guilty. Often times self-pity is an unconscious way of avoiding taking responsibility for personal actions or decisions made in the past. When we find it too difficult to accept the wrong that weve committed, sometimes we tend to hide from it by making ourselves the victims, rather than other people. In this case, self-pity is the perfect cowardly self-defense mechanism. So..... Laugh at yourself and at life. Not in the spirit of derision or whining self-pity, but as a remedy, a miracle drug. ~ Og Mandino Feeling sorry for yourself is normal, and in some instance can motivate you to face the realities of the seriousness of your disease. However, some make a habit out of self-pity, either to avoid taking personal responsibility, to avoid taking action, or simply to gain sickly and unhealthy forms of affection and attention from others. Something not to be applauded. If youve discovered that you struggle with this issue, be kind to yourself. Understand that self-pity is an unhealthy coping mechanism, but one that you can remove from your life with time, persistence, and patience. As Nancy, of Peanuts fame, tries to charge.....five cents please.

Posts.Title: AS no longer an option

Posts.Content: I also have a form (Behcet's Syndrome) of ulcerative colitis, Moonshadow. My cancer isn't as advanced as you father's, but the potential side effects of radiation have scared off a number of RO's, who have ALL said the dangers of any type of radiation on the rectum, during RT, could be severe. I still may have to look at radiation, after surgery. Please take care and insist that a good gastroenterologist is collaborating on all his treatment. In any future radiation, try to have a physician experienced with Hyrogel. It's the best protection that I know of currently available. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/843063 Good luck!

Posts.Title: Palliative Radiation and side effects on colitis

Posts.Content: Fascinating issue and question! The statistics and numbers must be recorded, but they are certainly held close to the vest, with most physicians and hospitals less than forthcoming unless their numbers are excellent. Not really surprising that they tend to be self promoting. Who wants to go to a doctor or hospital below the mean or average? As concerns prostate cancer, most of us are at an age that qualifies for Medicare, and they do keep detailed records and make them public for some procedures. https://projects.propublica.org/surgeons/ A telling question to ask your doctor is, " How do you know you're a successful physician, and what metrics do you measure yourself by? Try not to laugh at the squirming and double talk. Caveat Emptor!

Posts.Title: Probable Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Yep, Tony...you have persistent PSA, so speed is of the essence. On the remote chance the lab made an error, retest immediately. Also start SRT as soon as possible. You're still at a level where hormones (ADT) isn't mandatory, but please move quickly. 33 sessions of 2 Gys per session, yields you 66 Gy. Recent Standard Of Care practice, and four separate RO's, recommended no less than 70 Gy for me, so you may be looking at 2 more sessions. Work is important; life more so. IMHO get started in 3 weeks.....Good luck.

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: <<<My catheter came out six days after surgery, and since then I have been a "leaking machine" 98% of the time. My surgeon gave me a sheet of information that said the leakage would be at its worst during the first 2-3 weeks after surgery, which I can deal with. However, in paying close attention, I don't even seem to have the slightest bit of improvement yet. I'm not worried yet..... Obviously I have no choice right now but to be patient,.....But this is the one area (incontinence) that has me a little unnerved, simply because I am active in a lot of ways. I've more or less confined myself to my home for now because of potentially embarrassing situations.>>> Prostate cancer is inconvenient to ALL of us. I'd suggest relaxing and being patient for a while. You had surgery two weeks ago, your catheter came out one week ago, and your pathology looks very good. Your physician is on top of this. Oh, and internal worry can cause inflammation which in turn doesn't help continence. Count your blessings and give it a little time. It will get better!

Posts.Title: LabCorp...no better than Quest

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis Not sure most genomic tests tell if you have the brac2 gene malformation. However, I did use Decipher to inform my decision to treat or AS. Some don't agree on using this test for that purpose but my doc recommended it and I am glad I did. Denis Standard genome testing does NOT include BRAC2, and while Decipher is good for initial PCa treatment choice, the Oncotype Dx is a much better choice, because that is what is was designed for. Not surprising your admittedly relatively inexperienced URO didn't know this, Dennis. My URO at the time, didn't either. It’s important to talk to your doctor to find out if you are a candidate for genomic testing. There are a variety of tests with different strengths and weaknesses, and it's a still an evolving science: Oncotype Dx: This test looks at the activity of certain genes in the prostate tumor and assigns a personalized result, called the Genomic Prostate Score, to each case. This number predicts the chance that the disease will be more aggressive and spread to other parts of the body if left untreated. This is used after a confirmed prostate cancer diagnosis of low risk disease and uses biopsy tissue to predict likelihood of future growth and spread. It is helpful for those considering active surveillance...and would have been the best choice for Denis, but it worked out anyway. ProstaVysion: This test looks at a sequence of certain genes and provides a personalized genetic panel to determine aggressiveness. This is used after a confirmed prostate cancer diagnosis and uses biopsy tissue to predict likelihood of future growth and spread. It is helpful for those considering active surveillance. Prolaris Test: The Prolaris test measures how fast your cancer cells are dividing to predict aggressiveness. This is used after a confirmed prostate cancer diagnosis of low risk disease and can use both biopsy tissue and tissue from a radical prostatectomy to predict likelihood of metastasis, biochemical recurrence, and death from prostate cancer. It is helpful for men deciding on a treatment option or trying to decide on additional treatment after surgery. Decipher: Decipher Biopsy is available for patients diagnosed with localized prostate cancer at time of biopsy. Decipher Biopsy can help men and their doctors determine if it may be safe to consider active surveillance, treatment, or a combination of therapies. No additional procedure for the patient is needed to run this test. Decipher Post-Op predicts the likelihood of prostate cancer metastasis for men with adverse pathology after radical prostatectomy. The test can help patients and their doctors decide if additional treatment is needed after surgery. Decipher Post-Op uses a tissue sample that was removed during surgery, so no additional procedure for the patient is needed.

Posts.Title: @djin

Posts.Content: I don't know if he's one of the best, but he certainly is one of the most experienced. How much time did he personally give you? I'm surprised he doesn't want a 3T MRI to see what he's up against. At your age, you should do well with surgery. Press Patel for specific answers to all your questions. His PA's are very knowledgeable. He runs two surgeries simultaneously, or back to back, and does 6 or 8 a day. Always in a hurry, which has positives and negatives. Caveat Emptor & good luck!

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice?

Posts.Content: <<<My catheter came out six days after surgery, and since then I have been a "leaking machine" 98% of the time. My surgeon gave me a sheet of information that said the leakage would be at its worst during the first 2-3 weeks after surgery, which I can deal with. However, in paying close attention, I don't even seem to have the slightest bit of improvement yet. I'm not worried yet..... Obviously I have no choice right now but to be patient,.....But this is the one area (incontinence) that has me a little unnerved, simply because I am active in a lot of ways. I've more or less confined myself to my home for now because of potentially embarrassing situations.>>> Prostate cancer is inconvenient to ALL of us. I'd suggest relaxing and being patient for a while. You had surgery two weeks ago, your catheter came out one week ago, and your pathology looks very good. Your physician is on top of this. Oh, and internal worry can cause inflammation which in turn doesn't help continence. Count your blessings and give it a little time. It will get better!

Posts.Title: 16 months Post OP, I give up

Posts.Content: The Hopkins pathology reports are indeed a group effort, always review by the man, Dr. Epstein. Neither perineural invasion nor cribiform morphology are anything to lose sleep over. The pathology residents in training are just showing off. Christian Pavlovich, at Johns Hopkins is a superb surgeon, with some special talents. I also have dormant ulcerative colitis, and was told by a handful of RO's that surgery was my best option. I came very close to having it done at Johns Hopkins, but the logistics were too unwieldy. You won't go wrong listening to, and having treatment by Dr. Pavlovich. IMHO, no need to second guess him. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Early Salvage Radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Tim, Discussing post-op PSA rise, my doc reiterated that a rising PSA does sometimes stabilize, and cited the data JH presented when they originally suggested a PSA of 0.4 when the 0.2 level was established for BCR. As I've stated before, you have a very wise physician. My heart goes out the all our brothers anguish worrying about BCR, when the evidence of when it really occurs, and what the impact means, is so weak. Lots of business for radiation oncologists, however, along with years of follow up appointments for continued ADT, with similar weak evidence that the ADT really helps. Stay strong, you guys!

Posts.Title: Need lots of advice - PSA rising - results I didn't want to see

Posts.Content: Hi Steve, and welcome. I'm so sorry to hear of your miseries. While a prostate biopsy is not without risk, apparently not explained to you, the reactions you're suffering are extremely unusual. Your reaction, given the suffering you are enduring, is understandable. However, a prostate biopsy, done by a competent urologist, is a most valuable procedure for a cancer diagnosis. IMHO it's way to early to throw in the towel, but probably the right time to find better medical advise and treatment. Where are you located? The people on this Forum know, and are willing to share, so much. Please, if you will, share the history of your medical condition with us. There is hope, and you'll get experienced, and well reasoned advise here. Hoping and praying the worst is behind you, Steve.

Posts.Title: Dr. Bal Carter, at Johns Hopkins, retiring....

Posts.Content: Life can be full of stressful situations. It's little wonder that some struggle with things like anxiety, fear, and worry. This turmoil in their thinking, illogical though it may be, keeps them in a painful state of uneasiness—and limits them from truly experiencing the incredible joy that their otherwise blessed lives should allow. It is so important to rule one's emotions, fears and worry instead of having them rule you, even if it's only occasionally. Baseless and irrational fear most certainly does suck energy out of some, and insidiously, their loved ones, too. We can control ourselves, and stop these self destructive thoughts, for they do no good. The fear being discussed is nothing but self pity, IMHO. It is the enemy of healing. Neither dwell nor reflect on it. Taking control of one's emotions is as important as is getting good medical treatment. My prayer this Holiday season is for all to find the courage and power to eliminate these negative thoughts. Thankfully many have already. Bless you all.

Posts.Title: Shifting one's perspective

Posts.Content: Yep, Tony...you have persistent PSA, so speed is of the essence. On the remote chance the lab made an error, retest immediately. Also start SRT as soon as possible. You're still at a level where hormones (ADT) isn't mandatory, but please move quickly. 33 sessions of 2 Gys per session, yields you 66 Gy. Recent Standard Of Care practice, and four separate RO's, recommended no less than 70 Gy for me, so you may be looking at 2 more sessions. Work is important; life more so. IMHO get started in 3 weeks.....Good luck.

Au contraire...If you spend a little time searching around on this forum, you'll find that most ALL of us discuss, talk, 'admit' and advise each other on the most intimate of details, as Rob above has done for you. All is not lost, and there is much that can be done, usually starting with a positive attitude. You should soon get excellent advise from those much more experienced than I. In the meantime, please post your stats in your signature block, and surf around this informatively rich forum (i.e., "a sight like this"). You are neither alone, nor particularly unique. Have faith and best of luck.

Posts.Title: What to do at age 68?

Posts.Content: If it were me, Rob, and I wish it was....I'd pop the bubbly, jump for joy, say thanks for the radiation being so successful, say good riddance to all those dead cancer cells and forgo that last Lupron shot. But that's just me..... You can delay the last Lupron shot for a while and see what the next PSA reading tells you....hopefully the same .00 Do dying cancer cells really spew out lots of PSA I never heard that before.

Posts.Title: What to do at age 68?

Posts.Content: What was the recommendation of Bal Carter at JH? He is as good as it gets, and is expert about AS. Radiation, without ADT, isn't too bad, other than the time commitment. HDBRT may also be appropriate, but first: You should request a second reading of your husbands slides from Dr. Epstein. JH can get the slides, and coordinate with your insurance company. You also need an OncotypeDX genome test to access risk. Either call them directly (1-650-556-9300), or have JH do it. It should also be covered by insurance. Oh, and dump your local pompous URO. He is giving you poor advise. Good luck!

Posts.Title: PSA testing change 2017

Posts.Content: Good advise above Keith, that I concur with. One or two more uPSA checks, and have the most PCa experienced RO you can find ready to administer RT. Do some in-depth research on the need, in your specific case, for hormones (ADT). They may help, but how much is up for debate, and their side effects can be quite serious. Best of luck and please, keep us posted.

Posts.Content: I don't know if he's one of the best, but he certainly is one of the most experienced. How much time did he personally give you? I'm surprised he doesn't want a 3T MRI to see what he's up against. At your age, you should do well with surgery. Press Patel for specific answers to all your questions. His PA's are very knowledgeable. He runs two surgeries simultaneously, or back to back, and does 6 or 8 a day. Always in a hurry, which has positives and negatives. Caveat Emptor & good luck!

Posts.Title: New to cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Gary, how did the pre- and post-op Decipher results compare? I don't see either results in your sig. You may recall, we talked about this some time ago. My post biopsy (pre surgery) Decipher score was low risk 0.13 Risk of high grade disease was 9.5%, 5 year metastasis was 0.6%, and 10 year PCa mortality was 1.3% Post surgery my score increased to 0.37, 5 year metastasis 2.5%, and 10 year PCa mortality up to 3.3% Of course I didn’t know I had persistent PSA yet. My pre surgery OncotypeDX (GPS) predicted risk was intermediate, likelihood of favorable pathology of 63%, with a likelihood of low grade disease of 81% and a likelihood of organ confined disease of 80%

Posts.Title: BCR after Prostate Radiotherapy: The Case Against Early Androgen Deprivation

Posts.Content: As an update, I met with my RO this week and developed a plan regarding my Persistent PSA. Some others here have it and maybe this will help. By way of review I've have little leakage over the last three months, my ED symptoms are minimal, G 3+4=7 Grade Group 2, G pattern 4 = 10%, pT2c pN0 pMn/a, carcinoma organ confined in about 15% of the gland, EPE SV LN negative, PNI present, pathology verified by Dr. Epstein at JHMI. I did have one small positive anterior margin 0.1 mm long and limited < .3mm. My main concern is I've had ulcerative colitis for 45 years, and have had lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), a group of clinical symptoms involving my bladder, urethra, urinary sphincter and prostate for about 7 years. I had a TURP for it one and a half years ago that didn't alleviate the problems at all. So after two PSA's, both at .32 ng/mL, the alarms went off. I'll have another PSA tomorrow and yet another in 4 weeks. I will also get another Decipher Test; my first one was 15 months ago, and most importantly, I'll get an Axumin PET Scan, also know as a Fluciclovine (18F), or a anti-1-amino-3-18F-fluorocyclobutane-1-carboxylic acid(FACBC). It's specifically for those of us with suspected PCa recurrence based on elevated PSA levels. Then in four weeks, I'll meet with both my RO and my surgeon, so determine our next course of action. This also gives my system about four months to recover from surgery. My RO thinks I will need SRT and possible ADT. I'm going to investigate SBRT clinical trials for persistent PSA, and what I'd really like is some sort of active surveillance. Those RT side effects may be very daunting. Some articles I found that talk about Persistent PSA include: http://ascopubs.org/doi/full/10.1200/JCO.2005.08.904 http://ascopubs.org/doi/abs/10.1200/....32.4_suppl.32 http://ascopubs.org/doi/abs/10.1200/...5_suppl.e15041 http://ascopubs.org/doi/full/10.1200/JCO.2011.38.2788 http://ascopubs.org/doi/full/10.1200/JCO.2016.67.9647 I hope the above helps those in the same boat.

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice?

Posts.Content: As an RO, Chris Kline is as good as it gets, and as a patient advocate, so is Allen Edel who oddly doesn't participate on this forum. It's commonly held that Prostate cancer is often over treated. I'm starting to suspect the same holds true for A/SRT as well. Where are the studies on how successful it is at improving QoL and longevity? Lots of guys seem to jump on it early due to fear of BCR, in search of that elusive, and impossible, 'cure'. Just thinking out loud on a beautiful Sunday morning.

Posts.Title: Extraprostatic extension (EPE) and Adjuvant Radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Tim, Discussing post-op PSA rise, my doc reiterated that a rising PSA does sometimes stabilize, and cited the data JH presented when they originally suggested a PSA of 0.4 when the 0.2 level was established for BCR. As I've stated before, you have a very wise physician. My heart goes out the all our brothers anguish worrying about BCR, when the evidence of when it really occurs, and what the impact means, is so weak. Lots of business for radiation oncologists, however, along with years of follow up appointments for continued ADT, with similar weak evidence that the ADT really helps. Stay strong, you guys!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic All of us, after primary treatment, are in the same rescue boat, checking for leaks for years. There's no point or fun in worrying. Paddle on and enjoy the scenery! Very poetic Gerd....what your doc told you, "most likely isolated to the prostate, but there is a chance it snuck out..." is not really a catch. As DjinTonic so artistically points out, it's true for ALL of us, either forever or until we forget about it. Worrying about it will drive you crazy, so try to 'paddle on' and enjoy the holidays!
Posts.Signature: 72...LUTS for the past 7 years TURP 2/16, G3+4 discovered 3T MRI 5/16 MRI fusion guided biopsy 6/16 14 cores; four G 3+3, one G3+4, CIPRO antibiotic = C. Diff infection 7/16 Cured with Vanco for 14 days Second 3T MRI 1/17 Worsened bulging of posterior capsule Oncotype DX GPS 3/17, LFP risk 63%, Likelihood of Low Grade Disease 81%, Likelihood of Organ Confined 80% RALP 7/13/17 Dr. Gonzaglo @ Univ of Miami G3+4 Confirmed, Organ confined pT2c pNO pMn/a Grade 2 PSA 0.32 to .54 over 3 months DCFPyl PET & ercMRI Scans - 11/17 A one inch tumor remains in prostate bed = failed surgery All met scans clear SRT, 2ADT, IMGT 70.2 Gys @1.8 per, completed 5/18 PSA <.006 9/18, .054 11/18, .070 12/18, .067 2/19 We'll see....what is not known dwarfs what is thought to be fact
Posts.Title: Great news...with a catch!

Posts.Content: Getting a 3T Multiparametric MRI before your planned biopsy will allow it to be guided and much more accurate. Do a quick search on this Forum for lots a good data about it, and best of luck.

Posts.Title: One Year Anniversary

Posts.Content: <<<My catheter came out six days after surgery, and since then I have been a "leaking machine" 98% of the time. My surgeon gave me a sheet of information that said the leakage would be at its worst during the first 2-3 weeks after surgery, which I can deal with. However, in paying close attention, I don't even seem to have the slightest bit of improvement yet. I'm not worried yet..... Obviously I have no choice right now but to be patient,.....But this is the one area (incontinence) that has me a little unnerved, simply because I am active in a lot of ways. I've more or less confined myself to my home for now because of potentially embarrassing situations.>>> Prostate cancer is inconvenient to ALL of us. I'd suggest relaxing and being patient for a while. You had surgery two weeks ago, your catheter came out one week ago, and your pathology looks very good. Your physician is on top of this. Oh, and internal worry can cause inflammation which in turn doesn't help continence. Count your blessings and give it a little time. It will get better!

Posts.Title: One Day Post-op

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Tim, Discussing post-op PSA rise, my doc reiterated that a rising PSA does sometimes stabilize, and cited the data JH presented when they originally suggested a PSA of 0.4 when the 0.2 level was established for BCR. As I've stated before, you have a very wise physician. My heart goes out the all our brothers anguish worrying about BCR, when the evidence of when it really occurs, and what the impact means, is so weak. Lots of business for radiation oncologists, however, along with years of follow up appointments for continued ADT, with similar weak evidence that the ADT really helps. Stay strong, you guys!

Posts.Title: Need lots of advice - PSA rising - results I didn't want to see

Posts.Content: If you haven't, please see a good urologist, or internist. What you describe sounds more like prostatitis than prostate cancer. Your oncologist should be able to evaluate if your recent testicular cancer might be contributing to, or causing, your symptoms.

Posts.Title: Other PSA testing options - list needed

Posts.Content: I'm so sorry for what you, your family and your parents are enduring. I have 'Burgh family, love the city, but something is very odd with your dad's medical teams attitude. If at all possible TAKE your parents to Mayo ASAP. They need your hands-on help now!! I realize it may be difficult, but putting an octogenarian couple through this medical maze alone is IMHO, quite unreasonable. Best of luck; God keep you all; and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: First Post - My 81 Year Old Father - Prostate Cancer - Treatment Failure

Posts.Content: Hi Josey....even the wonderful physicians at MDA sometimes have conflicting goals, especially given their research expectations. That you are asking questions is excellent. You have a lot going on in your prostate, and I think the G3+4 might actually be higher. If it were me, and it was at one point, I would pull all the stops out to get a PSMA PET scan. The sooner the better. There are clinical trials you could qualify for, and, if need be, the out-of-pocket cost of a scan can be negotiated way down. If a scan doesn't indicate anything has escaped the barn, I would have a surgery already scheduled. Best of luck, and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: First Post - My 81 Year Old Father - Prostate Cancer - Treatment Failure

Posts.Content: The Hopkins pathology reports are indeed a group effort, always review by the man, Dr. Epstein. Neither perineural invasion nor cribiform morphology are anything to lose sleep over. The pathology residents in training are just showing off. Christian Pavlovich, at Johns Hopkins is a superb surgeon, with some special talents. I also have dormant ulcerative colitis, and was told by a handful of RO's that surgery was my best option. I came very close to having it done at Johns Hopkins, but the logistics were too unwieldy. You won't go wrong listening to, and having treatment by Dr. Pavlovich. IMHO, no need to second guess him. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: One Day Post-op

Posts.Content: Hi Josey....even the wonderful physicians at MDA sometimes have conflicting goals, especially given their research expectations. That you are asking questions is excellent. You have a lot going on in your prostate, and I think the G3+4 might actually be higher. If it were me, and it was at one point, I would pull all the stops out to get a PSMA PET scan. The sooner the better. There are clinical trials you could qualify for, and, if need be, the out-of-pocket cost of a scan can be negotiated way down. If a scan doesn't indicate anything has escaped the barn, I would have a surgery already scheduled. Best of luck, and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: When Things Get Worse, It's More Confusing

Posts.Content: Huckster Samadi doesn't deserve to be in the same conversation with superstars like Walsh and Carter. Samadi has been in trouble with the Feds, Medicare, and NY regulators, to name a few. Double bookings, excess testing, grandiose marketing claims, I spoke to him several times when I was searching, and got lots of baloney and "it's not covered by insurance" smoke blown in my face. Caveat Emptor, by brothers! https://nypost.com/2018/12/23/top-su...or-procedures/
